reviewText:
I got this game via Humble Bundle's monthly game subscription, and I mention this because I never would've gotten this game otherwise.  This game has surprised me in a few ways.  First off, I tried watching South Park when I was younger, and wasn't a fan of it in the slightest, so I assumed I wouldn't like this game.  Well, first surprise, I ended up enjoying it quite a lot.  The second way it surprised me was that ALL of the adult, raunchy humor you see in the show made its way into the game.  When I say all of it, I mean all of it!  In fact, its rating of 'M' has every category that the show does, including nudity, sexual content, and drug references.  I wasn't expecting to see South Park's full blown adult content in a video game.  If you look at some of my screenshots, you will see what I mean by this.  I'm no prude by any means, but some of the stuff in this game is why I never cared for South Park.

When you first start the game, you're given the option to create your own character.  You can choose skin color, hair color clothes, glasses, and one accessory.  While the customization is basic, it's very well done.  What really impressed me about this game was that during cut scenes I forgot I was playing a game.  It looks so much like the tv show, straight down to every animation, even the graphics style.  Wile on the topic of graphics, I never had issues with lag or FPS drops.  ST:TSoT is very well optimized, and runs good even on a laptop.

My biggest critique is with the combat system.  I realize this game is not intended to be some in depth combat game, but it could've been improved on.  Something I noticed frequently was that it didn't properly register when I blocked attacks.  I'd block them right on time, but it'd say I failed.  This seems to be a an issue within the game.  The combat system feels too much like Pokemon.  You attack, your oppnent attacks, use food or spell to revive, same thing over and over until someone's health is depleted.  I would've preferred if the combat system was a bit more unique.

SP:TSoT utilized very minimal quick time events that are used in combat for attacking and blocking.  The quick time event is quick time.  You have a second or less to respond or you fail, and when they're trying to teach you how to do it, you have to do it right in order to advance.  Not everyone has quick reflexes and can react in under a second.  I can already see people getting stuck and frustrated because they have to click that very second.

This game has full controller compatibility, and that earns it a huge plus.  I find that games like this do better with controllers.  One issue I noticed was that once a controller is plugged in, the mouse and keyboard cease to work in the game.  I do not understand why it has to be one or the other, and why both can't work at the same time.

Plot/Story wise, it reminded me of the old TV show Recess.  A bunch of kids just doing normal kid things that, to them, is serious/fun.  What I really enjoyed was that the entire story seemed to be based around kids roleplaying.  It wasn't anything real serious, just a relaxed, day-by-day of what these kids do.

Positives:
Had some very funny easter eggs and dialogue.
Stayed true to South Park's animation and feel.
Nice customization for character.
Runs pretty well even on a laptop.
Controller support.
Good plot.Negatives:
Poor combat system that didn't always register your reaction.
Game forced you to choose between controller or keyboard,couldn't use both.
Adult/sexual humor that went too far for a video game.


For more recommendations and reviews on our favourite up and coming quality games follow Lot's O Giveaway's, and check out our Curators.

reviewText:
Rating: 8.5/10
Overview: Turn Based RPG
Similar Games: Paper Mario

The Good:

+Possibly the stupidest, most juvenile, absurd, disgusting, raunchy, ridiculous, bizarre game I have ever played and for some reason I thought the game was brilliant. Yet despite its crude nature, the game has a charming quality underneath all of it, the characters are funny and well written and the game does a great job of representing the south park universe. Going around the town, speaking to all the characters, finding lots of secrets as you unlock new abilities is  fun and really rewards the player with some valuable things.


The Average:

The RPG mechanics and combat can be pretty basic especially for veterans in the genre. Turn based combat is pretty simple; melee, range and abilities you can use depending on the class you picked. You can equip many different types of equipment that grant bonuses but I never felt they really made that big of a difference in the long run.

The game also happens to be very easy even on normal mode. Play this game on hard if you want some challenge.


Conclusion:

I'm sure if you are a fan of South Park you have already completed the game; if you are not a fan than you should still play this game if you want a light hearted RPG experience. If you are the type of person that is overly sensitive, you may want to avoid this game.

reviewText: A love letter to South Park fans. Nearly everything from past episodes is referenced somewhere in the world, and the attention to detail goes above and beyond what I'd expect a game. Specific characters who you can completely avoid might make a joke if you do something specific, like farting or changing to a buddy (like swapping to Butters when you're in Professor Chaos' lair). The attention to detail on such small things is not something you see in many games. It feels just like an episode of South Park, comedic pacing and all.\n\nI had a few problems with the game. The shop system was probably made for a gamepad, since selling things takes too long. You'll find items which only exist to be sold, and you get them in bulk. You have to double click each and every single one, or if it's in a stack, select the item, then left click sell stack". It's not horrible but it takes longer than it needs to. The more important problem is that the game is just too damn easy. At the 10 hour mark I put the game on hardcore difficulty (which I never do because I'm a filthy casual)

reviewText:
TLDR: I loved it.

Currently I am about 6 hours through the game and I can tell any fan of South Park that this game is for them. Both blatantly and cleverly they have many references to the shows past storylines as well as awesome new content to be had.

The story has been a blast so far and the mechanics for battles are loads of fun. A turn based RPG with some control over the action is actually pretty damn sweet. (think paper mario)

I can highly suggest this to anyone looking for a light RPG game with tons of collectables and fun combat. As well to anyone that loves South Park.

Disclaimer:
For those that are offended easily the satire is ripe and raunchy while remaining smart and funny. They hold absolutely no punches in the Uncensored version. I can see it being absolutely devastating to anyone that is faint of heart. It gets pretty rude and crazy. I may be a monster, because while some stuff was wicked gross, I still laughed and never felt offended.

UPDATE:
I completed the game and stand by the statements I made originally, this game is fantastic and a total blast to play through. Nothing ever becomes overly tired like most RPGs, and it is hilarious through and through. Highly Recommend. One of the most polished and fun games I have ever played.

reviewText:
What can I say?


Its South Park alright and its JUST like the TV series we all love. Its brutal-honest, rude, sexist, racism and overall butt-jokes all over. I gotta say I was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at first because of the stupid region lock and censor version I get in germany but BOY....I sure as hell wouldnt let MY kid play this game.....no sir......not for the nazi signs but the overall expressions and topic of the game isnt for minors.

Okay so its South park all right. We love it and theres enough to laugh about. How does it fare regarding RPG mechanics?

Surprisingly its a solid even tho old-school system in place. The items and powers are good for a chuckle and give enough complexity to keep you min-maxing as it should" be. Whats new are the mini-games tied to combat attacks and moves. Its more then just buttom smashing and requires timing and overall awarness. I m not to the end yet but I m itching to restart the whole thing just with another class.

The save system is a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as you can only have one save at a time. It gets auto-updated whenever you do certain stuff in the game. You cannot save manually (well you can but it doesnt do what we expect it to do)

So far I feel like playing and watching an episode of South Park which is probably the best compliment you can give to this game. Atmosphere is great and I find myself laughing out lout often enough to keep drawing the attention of my wife and cats )

8/10

Theres only minor things distracting from a "perfect" experience. This well is well worth the prize if you are into RPGs :)"

reviewText:
Ah, South Park The Stick Of Truth. It took a year longer to release than it should've, but it's finally here. Is it the South Park game we've been waiting for ? 'Yes, absolutely !' is what I would say.

Let's start with the graphics. The graphics are similar to the TV show, meaning they are 2D and have a bit of a grainy look. It's like watching the 2D show, there are basically no differences here.

Gameplay wise it's similar to games like Paper Mario. You walk around the town completing quests, searching for loot and taking part in battles. Quests are handed out by the people of South Park and normally consist of defeating certain enemies or finding specific items. Most of these quests are simple and relatively easy to complete, which fits the game in a way, but thankfully the main quest has a bit more variation and depth.

Note that the whole game can be completed in 10-15 hours so it's not the biggest game we've ever seen or played. And that's a good thing, because near the end of the game it starts to overstay its welcome with its repetitive nature. 'Why', you ask ? Well, the battles are turn-based and except for some stronger enemies halfway through and near the end they never become exciting or very difficult. The special powers and summons are fun to use but you've probably seen most of it, or maybe all of it, within a couple of hours. And the fact that summons can't be used for boss fights is slightly disappointing.

The humor is just fantastic, as is the voice acting. You can tell a lot of work and love was put into it. This is one of the reasons you should play The Stick Of Truth. There's some hilarious stuff in it.
One small thing that doesn't really affect my opinion of the game but should be said anyway is the fact that some of the collectibles can't be collected anymore once you've finished the story. So, to all completionists out there; make sure you grab everything before wrapping up the story.

Anyway, to wrap up my review:
South Park The Stick Of Truth is the South Park game we've been waiting for and if you even remotely enjoy the show you owe it to yourself to play it at least once. You'll have a good time with it, believe me.

[Rating: 86/100]

reviewText:
Stick of Truth is a turn based RPG which has you exploring the town of South Park while the kids in town are waging a pretend war between humans and elves. We play as a silent protagonist known as “new kid” and quickly gets forced into the fake war due to his inability to talk. In that time they will learn you have an amazing ability to fart and declare you are Dragonborn. Yep, very much South Park humor and flawlessly brought over from the show. For those that don't know what South Park is or have never seen it, it is a comedy show that loves to use very offensive humor toward religion, homosexuals, abortions and pretty much anything under the sun. If you get offended over those type of jokes don't play this game because it holds no punches back and features nudity, sex, bestiality and stuff that may get this review taken down if I mention them due to the extreme nature of the acts. Nonetheless, it is a very good thing they didn't censor anything adapting the shows humor into a video game.

But how is it as a game, you may be asking by now. Well it is pretty entertaining at first as you see what wacky moves characters have and the battle dialogue is still fresh but lose their charm after the 50th time and is further worsened due to some abilities you need to button mash on. It's not all bad though, you can can block an enemies attack if you press the guard button at the right time to lessen the damage you receive and that feature really lends the fights more interactivity and a big reason to pay attention instead of just lazily selecting moves from a list all the time. The strategy never gets too deep considering you can only have one ally fighting with you but that may be for the best, even being outnumbered the game is a tad on the easy side. When you are not fighting you will be exploring South Park and helping characters with their problems. After looting all their drawers of course.

Money isn't really hard to get if you like looting through every shiny object you pass by. With that cash you can buy items, armor and weapons which is pretty standard for RPGs. The difference in this is that all objects are unique so you wont be finding a similar looking weapon with just higher stats. You will get your hands on stuff that a child probably could at first like lighters, dodge-balls and wands but eventually get your hands on pretty dangerous objects like hammers or knifes. On top of that you can enchant your weapons to add status effects. It also features a pretty simply upgrade tree and perks you can get by adding friends on Facebook, usually by helping them with a quest. You traverse through the town in a 2D background but can move between the background and foreground like a regular 3D game. There are also occasional puzzles which usually involve farting on something and will usually lead you to one of the games many collectibles.

Graphics in this game capture  the feel of the show flawlessly. Everything looks like it was made of paper cutouts and all walk in the same low budget style of the show for that signature South Park charm. Attacks are well animated and the high level abilities are always a joy to watch especially Kenny's. Characters all look like in the show and seeing them dressed up in medieval gears is amusing. The town all looks the same and they managed to connect the areas seen in the show into a natural feeling world map. User Interface is simple and efficient but the screens to access gear and skills is a bit cluttered. Enemy variety is pretty good but including elves, rats and all matter of crazy stuff that I won't mention to avoid spoilers. Also male genitals have quite a bit of detail to them having hairs and veins etc. Is that a good feature? I don't know that depends on the person..

Sound design is also flawlessly brought over from the show. Every character has their original voice actor and they don't half ♥♥♥ their roles in this game. The music is very South Parky including epic background music of Cartman singing about the Jewish. Sounds effects all sound very well done especially the blocking sound effect that sounds like steel clashing even though there is no steel. Stores feature some songs from the show like “Vote or Die” which I found hilarious listening to that in a Chinese restaurant.  Only bad thing I can say about the sound is that characters start moaning after you don't press a button for about five seconds or when you are not doing quests which is funny at first but quickly got pretty annoying.

Story feels like one really awesome special episode of South Park. From start to finish it takes unexpected and often hilarious turns in true South Park fashion. Even the side-quests have their own funny mini stories with characters that don't get air time on the main plot. You travel to bizarre places in this game outside of the town of South Park including Canada for the silliest reason. It is quite hilarious seeing how seriously characters take their pretend war and the Stick of Truth which is said to control the universe. I won't explain much more about the story but believe me it captures the soul of the show perfectly.

Stick of Truth lasted me about 12 hours and I estimate it would last 14-15 if you want to complete everything. It was the perfect length and kept the plot-line from getting stale or the combat to get boring. I don't really see a reason to replay it unless you want to try a different class and are going for achievements. It is a really solid RPG for those looking for a game filled with dark humor or can tolerate it. This game completely captures the soul and style of the show in every conceivable way and is without a doubt a must have for fans of the show.

reviewText:
Stick of Truth is a turn based RPG which has you exploring the town of South Park while the kids in town are waging a pretend war between humans and elves. We play as a silent protagonist known as “new kid” and quickly gets forced into the fake war due to his inability to talk. In that time they will learn you have an amazing ability to fart and declare you are Dragonborn. Yep, very much South Park humor and flawlessly brought over from the show. For those that don't know what South Park is or have never seen it, it is a comedy show that loves to use very offensive humor toward religion, homosexuals, abortions and pretty much anything under the sun. If you get offended over those type of jokes don't play this game because it holds no punches back and features nudity, sex, bestiality and stuff that may get this review taken down if I mention them due to the extreme nature of the acts. Nonetheless, it is a very good thing they didn't censor anything adapting the shows humor into a video game.

But how is it as a game, you may be asking by now. Well it is pretty entertaining at first as you see what wacky moves characters have and the battle dialogue is still fresh but lose their charm after the 50th time and is further worsened due to some abilities you need to button mash on. It's not all bad though, you can can block an enemies attack if you press the guard button at the right time to lessen the damage you receive and that feature really lends the fights more interactivity and a big reason to pay attention instead of just lazily selecting moves from a list all the time. The strategy never gets too deep considering you can only have one ally fighting with you but that may be for the best, even being outnumbered the game is a tad on the easy side. When you are not fighting you will be exploring South Park and helping characters with their problems. After looting all their drawers of course.

Money isn't really hard to get if you like looting through every shiny object you pass by. With that cash you can buy items, armor and weapons which is pretty standard for RPGs. The difference in this is that all objects are unique so you wont be finding a similar looking weapon with just higher stats. You will get your hands on stuff that a child probably could at first like lighters, dodge-balls and wands but eventually get your hands on pretty dangerous objects like hammers or knifes. On top of that you can enchant your weapons to add status effects. It also features a pretty simply upgrade tree and perks you can get by adding friends on Facebook, usually by helping them with a quest. You traverse through the town in a 2D background but can move between the background and foreground like a regular 3D game. There are also occasional puzzles which usually involve farting on something and will usually lead you to one of the games many collectibles.

Graphics in this game capture  the feel of the show flawlessly. Everything looks like it was made of paper cutouts and all walk in the same low budget style of the show for that signature South Park charm. Attacks are well animated and the high level abilities are always a joy to watch especially Kenny's. Characters all look like in the show and seeing them dressed up in medieval gears is amusing. The town all looks the same and they managed to connect the areas seen in the show into a natural feeling world map. User Interface is simple and efficient but the screens to access gear and skills is a bit cluttered. Enemy variety is pretty good but including elves, rats and all matter of crazy stuff that I won't mention to avoid spoilers. Also male genitals have quite a bit of detail to them having hairs and veins etc. Is that a good feature? I don't know that depends on the person..

Sound design is also flawlessly brought over from the show. Every character has their original voice actor and they don't half ♥♥♥ their roles in this game. The music is very South Parky including epic background music of Cartman singing about the Jewish. Sounds effects all sound very well done especially the blocking sound effect that sounds like steel clashing even though there is no steel. Stores feature some songs from the show like “Vote or Die” which I found hilarious listening to that in a Chinese restaurant.  Only bad thing I can say about the sound is that characters start moaning after you don't press a button for about five seconds or when you are not doing quests which is funny at first but quickly got pretty annoying.

Story feels like one really awesome special episode of South Park. From start to finish it takes unexpected and often hilarious turns in true South Park fashion. Even the side-quests have their own funny mini stories with characters that don't get air time on the main plot. You travel to bizarre places in this game outside of the town of South Park including Canada for the silliest reason. It is quite hilarious seeing how seriously characters take their pretend war and the Stick of Truth which is said to control the universe. I won't explain much more about the story but believe me it captures the soul of the show perfectly.

Stick of Truth lasted me about 12 hours and I estimate it would last 14-15 if you want to complete everything. It was the perfect length and kept the plot-line from getting stale or the combat to get boring. I don't really see a reason to replay it unless you want to try a different class and are going for achievements. It is a really solid RPG for those looking for a game filled with dark humor or can tolerate it. This game completely captures the soul and style of the show in every conceivable way and is without a doubt a must have for fans of the show.

reviewText:
Note to people looking to buy (Important): I bought this during a Steam sale... the 40 dollar price mark is too high for a game that only runs around a few days of hardcore playing to beat. It's a great value if you can catch it on sale... I would have never bought it at the normal price-mark (but I am glad I got it on sale, was totally worth paying a few bucks for)

Bought this on a whim without knowing anything about the game and was very happy I did. I have never laughed so much playing an RPG in my life. This was a surprise hit for me. I really hope that South Park continues to make RPG games. They translated the show into a game effectively. It really feels like you are running around South Park trying to figure out what the heck is going on.

Parental Warning: they did not censor themselves in this game in any fashion. They really pushed the line of what I thought would even be allowed in games as far as thematic content (in the best way, this is just a warning to parents looking to buy this for their children, this isn't a kids show to begin with) It's just as adult as the show (which is a great thing for show fans)

If you are considering getting this game and are a South Park fan, you WILL NOT be disappointed. I never thought I'd enjoy beating up little kids in a game. I was WRONG. It is supremely satisfyingly side splittingly funny.

A+

reviewText:
An exciting discovery, South Park: The Stick of Truth is actually a very good RPG.  The story is, to put it bluntly, fantastic as it feels like I played a fourteen hour South Park episode where I was starring as a fellow eight year old who has moved to the small town.  The mechanics are relatively simple but entertaining and engaging enough that they didn't feel like a negative aspect at any point in the game.

The game is packed full of adventures that are new and yet familiar for any fans, or even casual watchers, of South Park.  You'll be running around all over South Park and the surrounding area and getting into trouble with all of your favorite characters throughout.  I haven't watched as much of the show as I would like though the person I was playing it with is a huge fan and we both laughed our asses off through the entirety of it all the same.  It even led to her bringing up clips of what certain items and locations were in reference to which made the game all that much more enjoyable.

The combat mechanics are similar to what I remember of Mario RPG in that every character has a variety of abilities that require pressing buttons at the right time or rotating the stick to get the full effect.  It kept combat interesting and engaging even with the relatively simple system.  The item system was fun as you find the most obnoxious weapons and gear and you can customize them with strap-ons" that you find.

I had twice the blast I was expecting from this game and I was expecting a good game.  I highly recommend this game to RPG gamers
recommended: and anyone looking for an extremely inappropriate adventure involving elves

reviewText:
If you're a fan of South Park, purchasing this is a no-brainer. I'm so happy this game was as good as I hoped it would be and more. I used to play loads of turn-based RPGs back in the day but eventually became disinterested with them after a couple disappointing titles (Star Ocean 4, Tales of Vesperia and Final Corridor XIII), but Obsidian have created a combat system which is both simple and yet has complexities which fits perfectly with Trey Parker and Matt Stone's hilarious writing and sense of humour. At several points during this game I had to stop playing because I was laughing so hard.

Being an Obsidian game, I was expecting a ton of bugs but surprisingly enough there were very few (mainly some patch equipping and stuck in cutscenes issues). I'm glad they took time to hire a competent QA department this time round as I think the amount of bugs present in Fallout: New Vegas upon release unfortunately impacted the reception of a game which ultimately was better than Fallout 3 in many ways.

The Stick of Truth is one of those games where you can't talk about it in much detail with someone who is a fan of South Park but has yet to play it, because you don't want to spoil the sheer enjoyment they'll have from playing this game. You're actually excited for them to play and experience it for themselves - it's that ♥♥♥♥ing good.

reviewText:
Thanks to Obsidian and South Park Digital Studios for make this awesome game. If you are a fan of the series dont think it twice and BUY IT NOW.

+Story
The game is at the quality of the series and there can be no better success. Everything you know of South Park is in the game and the entire game it's like a special episode but you can form part of it. You can burst the face to Al Gore, it's what all of us want when we are watching the series.
+Combat
A RPG with turn-based combat and it is not boring... YES! finally! has been a while. The special attacks of every character are amazing and funny if you dont laugh playing Princess Kenny, seriously, go to doctor.
I recommend playing this in Hardcore difficulty, normal and casual it's just too easy and boring. Nothing can kill you and even the boss battles is just press a single key and see ya.
+Music
We have all the greatest hits of the series, Faith +1, Jennifer Lopez and his tacos, I'm a Little Bit Country... A lot of songs you've heard before but the OST of the game is also great and it's full of references of other franchises (Zelda, TES, Castlevania...). Jimmy songs are AWESOME.
+Map
Well, we can explore the entire town of South Park and even Canada! well, the map is not very huge but well it's a town.
+Customization
This is a RPG and this needs a lot of items, armors, hairs and stuff like that and in this one you have all of that and even more. The amount of crazy and stupid items there is insane. You will not have complaints about this.
+Cartman
Because he always make you laugh. It's a safe bet.

-Duration
I played 15.6 hours and I almost have everything in the game. I just need do 2 or 3 side-quest and It's done except the collectibles.
-Butters
Because he is always insufferable.

It's a game completly oriented to the fans. Buy it, M'kay? and remember never fart on another man's balls. Dont broke the gentleman's code.

reviewText:
This game is simply amazing. Most tie in games are terrible and made only to make money or cash in on something that is popular at the moment.  Trey and Matt, along with Obsidian Ent. have crafted a wonderful game that looks and feels like South Park, on top of being very fun to play.

This has been a dream type game for me over the years, something I would create in Game Dev Tycoon... take my favorite rpg developers and stick them with working with the south park writers on a south park RPG. It looks and feels like the damn tv show for crying out loud! Obsidian has done it again, managed to keep me glued to the monitor hours into the night. I have never laughed anywhere close to this much during a game, it is laugh out loud hilarious and will have you on the floor laughing non stop.

There could be more pc settings and it could use a little balance in difficulty but those are the only negatives I can think of. The combat is fun, the story and writing is top notch, as is the atmosphere and the controls. They could have done a crap game and made money with the South Park license but instead the writers and Obsidian have put there heart and soul into this game.

If you are a South Park fan or an Obsidian fan like me, don't even think twice go and buy this game ASAP. If you are on the fence about this game go read Giantbombs revierw (5/5), PC gamers review or even go watch Total Biscuits WTF is South Park vide on youtube, agree with those the most so far. Only 3-4 hours into it so far but boy have I had a blast! Cartman and all you're favorite south park characters are here as you (The new Kid in town) go on adventures while laughing your ♥♥♥ off.

MUST OWN game, Obsidian and Trey/Matt deserve a pat on the back for a job well done. You can tell it was made with a ton of love and not just as a money cash in.

reviewText:
I Havent enjoyed a game this much in years, and here are a few reason why;

- You are a new kid, which works because you get to experence playing with the cast of south park
- Magic farts
- Every character you love is in it (even a few surprise appearances)
- Turn based combat with some depth
- Ways to win battles without fighting
- 3 levels of difficulty (i played on normal and i had a few hard moments)
- Butters, Jimmy, Kenny, Cartman, Kyle, or Stan fight with you
- Tons of surprises for fans of the tv series
- Collectibles (i got them all during my 14 hour run of the game)

There are some things wrong with the game, they didnt ruin my experience but it may for some;

- Travel in South park is tedius
- Combat is too simple after you get the hang of it
- Not much to do after you beat the game; no end game content or new game plus

reviewText:
The world's very first playable episode of South Park. (The other ones don't count.)

All of the crassness, offensive humor, and ridiculousness of the show, going on for about 15 hours of Paper-Mario-esque Turn-Based RPG Gameplay.

If that sounds good to you, South Park: The Stick of Truth, might be the game for you. Otherwise, avoid.

reviewText:
Game of the Year 2014 for sure.

The story is funny from start to finish, including most of the side quests. It's everything you'd expect from South Park. It's extreme, profane, obscene, and often disturbing.

The game mechanics are excellent. The various status effects are meaningful and useful. Each character has different abilities both in and out of combat. The game features mostly standard turn-based RPG mechanics, but mixes it up a bit. For example, using the bard's lullaby song requires you to perform a miniature version of Dance Dance Revolution. In the world map, it's more of an adventure game with very simple puzzle elements. Later in the game, the developers mix things up in the world map when you go to Canada and it switches to a top-down retro RPG view.

There are loads of collectables. You collect Facebook friends throughout town. You collect Pokemon knock off figures. You collect costumes and equipment. There's a lot of equipment, but none of it feels arbitrary. Depending on your play style, you can find a use for just about every piece of equipment. There are enhancement items to modify your equipment with that augment your play style.

The DLC are worthless really. The items are level 2 and are quickly replaced by better equipment. I bought them, but didn't use them.

I don't know if I'd say the game has replay value. I enjoyed it a lot, but once the story is over, there is a limited amount of side quests to finish. The game is pure fun from start to finish and definitely worth at least one play through.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game captures the spirit of South Park really well, and perhaps more surprisingly, has legitimately interesting and fun mechanics. The combat is fun, out of combat is fun, the story is fun, and, of course, the characters are fun. It's entertaining enough that you can play while someone watches and they won't get bored (my girl sat through the whole damn thing). It's not very long though, which isn't so much a hit against it, as it was just the right length to pick up and beat in a weekend (along with all the side quests).

I will also say that it's not very challenging however. The pacing promises that you will always have more abilities than you'll really know what to do with, money and items come easily, and if you pay enough attention to the mechanics to have a specific build, you will steamroll most encounters (although the enemy variety may muck you up if you're too focused around one subset of mechanics).

If I had to gripe about anything, it would be the inventory which felt clunky, and was organized alphabetically rather than say by level (the name of an item doesn't really provide as much context as the level requirements).

Totally worth the sale price. Eagerly awaiting the sequel (or DLC xpac).

reviewText:
Gameplay: Relatively simply turn-based combat, made interesting with many different weapons, spells, items and other variables that keep the action consistently engaging and fun throughout the game. There are also many different types of enemies that help to keep up combat variety (although there are occassional difficulty spikes with certain bosses). As you go through the campaign, you will unlock new abilities that will unlock previously unlockable parts of the map, which encourages you to explore the levels and also revisit them later on.

Story: Typical South Park fare, well written with plenty of satire, relating to various worldwide events, art pieces and celebrities. The story has many twists and is deeper than it initially seems. Many of the side quests are creatively designed, with interesting plots and characters.

Graphics: The game looks just like an actual episode of South Park, the animation is perfectly done and brings the town of South Park and its inhabitants to life. Each location is overflowing with various references to seasons 1 to 17 and each character/item/location is based on some aspect of the ongoing South Park canon.

Sound: Each character is authentically voiced, and often have very funny dialogues. A surprising amount of wit is injected into various minor remarks and it is definitely worth exploring each characters range of lines. As well as the voice acting, the music is very well done, with various songs from throughout the multitude of South Park seasons (and even certain songs from the movies) making an appearance throughout the game. Just as good as these songs is the game's original soundtrack, which is an epic, lustrous score.

Re-playability: The town of South Park is littered with collectables and loot, with quests abounding and secrets ever-present in each section. Replaying the game is also incentivised by the inclusion of character-specific achievements and abilities, and will be essential for the completionist or OCD afflicted.

The best part is, It doesn't feel like a game, It feels more like an entire series of South Park with you as the main character. reviewText:
I must say that all of the reviews were just about spot on.

The game is roughly 15 hours long if you knock out all the side quests and get caught up in trying to pop some achievements. The gameplay is easy, the story is fantastic, and it's just a really well made game.

You do get level capped at 15, and on normal you can easily take out waves of enemies.

With all that being said I am easily going to play this again and possible again as this is the first game I actually want to 100% in a long time. It doesn't try to re-write the rules of how a game should be played, but it breaks everything down to it's simpliest form and then slightly expands it on gradually.

If they do make a sequal I hope there is more to do after end-game, more make the main storyline longer. But honestly it's a minor gripe.

10/10 - Would Douchbag Again.

reviewText: I finally beat it this morning. I have to say that was a lot of laughs and a lot of fun.  Hardcore RPG players may not enjoy it as much as it sort of feels like it is on rails, but there are still a lot of secrets to uncover.  The fighting system is done in the same vein of JRPGs, but it knows it's other RPGs well. It makes fun of the things you always think about in an RPG while being what it does best. Offensive, Abusive and very very sexually crude.  It's Southpark and if you are a fan of it even slightly. You will appreciate this game.  I personally was not expecting very much from it. I was hoping to laugh, but I got so much more from it. It made me laugh more than I think I have laughed during a game before.  It shows that Trey and Matt really did the right thing by standing by it's side during the making of it.  I have heard a lot of people saying that the game is only 14 hours long. I have played it longer than that by looking for secrets and getting everything I can out of the game.  I have also hear that there is no replay ability with the game.  I disagree.  Reason being.  I felt like i was actually IN Southpark.  I would say it's like playing a hillarioius movie.  If you like a movie. You are gonna watch it again.  If you like Southpark. You are probably going to watch episodes again.  So if you like those things. You will love the game. Those seeking a little bit of challenge I would say put it up past normal".  There are a few parts that take a bit of thinking and pairing of your buddies. If I had to rate this. I would break it into 2 categories. Fun 9.5/10  Gameplay 8.0/10.   Giving it and 8.75 total. If you are not a fan of Southpark. You might want to overlook it.  While you can still enjoy it. It won't be the same great experience that I had with it."

reviewText:
In brief: extremely high quality RPG that will definitely NOT appeal to anyone who doesn't like South Park.

In boxers: Although South Park has had several games in the past (most notably the incredibly dull Turok 2 TC), it's only in recent years that the makers of the show, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, have been directly involved in the making of any tie-in games, and it shows. The quality of these games has improved dramatically, finally culminating in The Stick of Truth, a truly fantastic experience that feels like a true labour of love from everyone involved.

Playing as The New Kid (who you can customize to an almost insane degree), you barely last 30 seconds outside before  you're drawn in to the Warriors and Wizards-style LARPing of the other South Park kids, joining up with Cartman and (Princess) Kenny's humans to take on Stan and Kyle's Drow Elves for possession of the titular Stick of Truth - which is blatantly just a Macguffin designed to keep the game going.

Trey and Matt directly approached Obsidian Entertainment to develop this game due to Trey's love of RPGs, and it turned out to be an inspired choice. The game is an RPG through and through, and a pretty damn good one at that. There are four character classes you can choose from - Warrior, Mage, Thief and (of course) Jew - though aside from the special attacks each class gains, there's really not a whole lot of difference between each one. It's the combat where the differences to standard JRPGs show up to add variety to things.

First is the addition of quick-time style button prompts when attacking or defending which allow you to increase the damage you dish out or reduce the amount you take. Learning to use this is not only massively helpful in battle, but it also means you never feel uninvolved in combat, which is a welcome change from the norm. You can also use an item AND attack in the same turn, which, while offering a large degree of tactical usefulness, does mean that combat rarely becomes particularly challenging as a result, especially once you discover the importance of status effects.

There's four main effects you can apply to enemies - Bleeding, Freezing, Grossed Out and On Fire. Each of these has its own pros and cons, but once you realise how easy it is to apply them (especially once you find ranged weapons that can hit multiple opponents), you'll quickly come to find that combat loses a huge amount of its appeal and ends up losing a lot of its appeal as a result.

That said, if the combat ends up becoming a bit of a chore, then it's fortunate that little else about the game does.There is a surprisingly large amount to do in this game, from finding Jesus (twice) to catching all the Chinpokemon to dealing with the homeless problem, there's an absolute ton of things to do around South Park, which is rendered absolutely perfectly. It really does look and feel exactly like the TV show, to the point where anyone passing by might ask you what episode you're watching. A huge amount of work has gone into making this a faithful adaptation, and it shows.

Length-wise, the game will last you anywhere between 12-15 hours, which may seem short, but unlike most RPGs there's very little wasted time here. The level cap is 15, which you'll hit around the 2/3rds point, and once you hit that you can pretty much just avoid combat entirely and focus on finishing the story, which is every bit as insane as the show itself, taking in aliens, goth kids, cootie-ridden girls, abortions, Zombie Nazis and Canada. Not necessarily in that order.

Trey and Matt voice the majority of the characters as in the show, along with a few others helping them along the way, and although a few characters sound a little off (Officer Barbrady in particular sounds like someone doing an impression of him rather than the original voice actor) there's a huge number of characters from the show's history on display here in one form or another. There's a few people missing, but then again if they included everyone there wouldn't be much wiggle room for a sequel now, would there?

Some people will tell you that there's plenty of replayability to be had, but those people are talking out of their anal probes. There's few differences between classes, rendering that aspect rather pointless, and there's only one point where the plot splits... which lasts all of 30 minutes before both paths snap back into one. Any replayability to be gained is simply from wanting to experience the plot elements a second time, which is certainly valid, but this really isn't a game designed to be played over and over again.

Which leads to the price. I can't help feeling that paying full price for this game is really justified. It may be a good game - and trust me, it's VERY good - but on Steam they're asking for £40, which is far too much. It's worth around half that. Also, don't bother purchasing the clothing packs (the 'Samurai Spaceman' and 'Ultimate Fellowship' bundles), as they simply add extra outfits that, while nice, don't really add anything to the game itself and serve only as basic pre-order nonsense. If they decide to release story-based DLC (and I hope they do!), then that'll be worth a look, but I wouldn't recommend anything else.

This is very much a South Park game first and an RPG second, so if you're not willing to get on board with the twisted, insane humour of the show then you won't find much to entertain you here, especially once the game really gets going. But for everyone else, this is a fantastic game with few flaws that I have absolutely no hesitation in recommending.

Because really, what other game lets you throw a bloody tampon at enemies, then whack them with a giant ♥♥♥♥♥, gross them out, circumcise them, cause them to bleed into unconsciousness and then fart on them when they're lying beaten and broken on the ground? (And no, I'm not making a word of that up.)

reviewText:
South Park: The Stick of Truth is a brilliant hilarious game,
That brings the crude humour of South Park and mixes it with solid Turn Based Combat.
One of the funnest gaming experiences I had in 2014.

Pros
+Hilarious story, with loads of references to the show that fans of south park will love.
+Good amount of customization.
+Loads of unique levels and areas keep the gaming feeling fresh.
+Lots of favourite characters from the show voiced by the real actors.

=Combat is solid, however as the game progresses I feel like you become hugely over powered by the end.

Cons
-For an RPG, the game is very short. Completed it in a litte over 12 hours.
-Would of liked to have seen more sidequests to give it more longevity.

Final thoughts
All in all, this is a very solid game that fans of the show should not miss. However if you are not a fan of the show or do not enjoy crude humour then this game is not for you, as it is around every corner.

reviewText: Fantastic game. Took me roughly 14 hours to finish, making it alot longer of a game than I figured it would be. Replay value is definetely there, with each class (mage, warrior, thief, and jew) all having their unique abilities and playstyles. I do plan to playthrough one more time, as there is also room to miss some stuff (collectables and what not, appealing to perfectionists). The gameplay itself manages to not become too repititive, with new enemies and buddies (companions) constantly being introduced. Finally, if you enjoy the humor that the show contains, then this game is pretty much just that. Long time fans will love all the referances to past episodes there are, but theres still plenty of new material for anyone somewhat new to South Park.

reviewText: Probably one of the better PC games to be made from a liscenced property since......Beavis and Butthead in Virtual Stupidity" maybe?   It perfectly translates the look and tone of the TV show to a video game format.  Which isn't to say it's perfect
recommended: either as an RPG or as a piece of "South Park."  As an RPG
hoursPlayed: the game mechanics are there for a good amount of depth.  Attacks do different types of damage
voteText: special moves often involve the stacking of various status effects to do maximum damage
helpfulPercent: and enemies have different vulnerabilities. So theoretically the game's mechanics could be used to design some fairly interesting fights.  Unfortunately
votesHelpful: even on the hardest difficulty fights are incredibly easy.  Special attacks do so much damage that you usually don't have to worry about what type of damage you are doing
votesTotal: to the point that one wonders why the designers bothered implementing the various damage types and status effects at all.  I can't think of a game that would benefit more from a fan made difficulty mod than this as the potential for depth is there in the game's mechanics
votesFunny: it's just that the designers never really tap into this depth in combat design.\n\nAs "South Park" the game is much better
commentsCount: although it does suffer from the repetition of way too many jokes from the TV show.  This is especially troublesome in instances where these recycled bits come from later in the series run and thus were never that funny in their first incarnation (see
column16: for example
column17: Morgan Freeman gets a freckle).  However
column18: the game does have many inspired moments all its own (a sex scene fight that I won't go into detail over lest I spoil it sticks out in particular) and ultimately part of this is probably due to the length of the game's development more than anything (Parker and Stone canabalized a good deal of the game's storyline in their Game of Thrones themed
column19: three part episode last season
column20: which ended up stealing the game's thunder somewhat.  I suspect some of these jokes would have had more impact had the game been released first
column21: as it was originally planned).   Most importantly
column22: though
column23: even if the jokes occasionally fall flat
column24: the game works first and foremost as a narrative.  The game's central conceit of basing an RPG around kids playing fantasy dress up is brilliant and Parker and Stone are good enough at adapting their story telling and humor to video games as a medium that it kind of makes me wish that they'd write an original RPG.\n\nIn the end
column25: this is a solid
column26: if uninspired
column27: RPG despite its gameplay flaws and
column29: represents "South Park" at its most epic and comprehensive. Parker and Stone haven't tried to go this big
column30: in terms of the scope of the series
column33: and Uncut."  Given that the game reaches so much farther than the show has in years
column34: it's slightly easier to forgive the overreliance on recycled material."

reviewText: Sick, Twisted and full of dark humor - not for everyone, but if your a South Park fan then this game is a must.  Whilst the game itself does have a few minor issues, especially with balance as some fights can be exceptionally easy and others, brutally difficult these issues don't really get in the way of progressing through the game.\n\nThe game itself is slightly on the short side, but the journey through the game is very good, imagine your the main character in a south park episode, this is basically what the Stick of Truth is - your the main character in a rather sick and twisted episode, and its a rollercoaster ride of a blast from start to finish.

reviewText:
Start this game expecting a decent South Park game. It turns out better than my expectation.

- An enjoyable RPG.
- The story kept my interest throughout the game.
- The content is good enough and doesn't feel draggy. The collectibles are fun to search and collect.
- The turn based combat mechanics are not too complex but also not too simple. Although your starting job might impact your battle experience throughout the game. The companion system allows you to determine your own combat strats.
- The most important thing is that it is a South Park game first . Every element in this game has that South Park feel.

Would recommend to others. Onto the next game!

reviewText: I'm going to say this is one of the best RPG's ever made in my opinion. Yes, it IS short, be warned about that beforehand, you'll finish the game in 25 hours if you take your sweet time, and you should, because what makes this game so good it's the amount of detail put into it. Rushing past everything would be playing this game wrong, this isn't to be played in a hurry. Actually, the game expects a little of thinking and observation from your part with a lot of puzzles, for example those optional ones to take down enemies without the need to fight them.\n\nEven if you're not a fan of the TV series or RPG's in general you'll find that this is a well made game, with a good flow both in history and combat. The battle and overworld mechanics are fresh, entertaining and feel just right. Obviously there is a lot of foul language and even things that people might find objectionable, but that and it's blend of comedy put into a videogame is what makes this one a unique experience you will never find elsewhere nowhere soon, because what the creators of this game took is a big risk, the kind of risk that videogame developers are less and less likely to take when it comes to games of this budget. Why? Because the game has no real replay value, all the effort that was put into this game, you will experience it in it's single run. No grinds, no replays, no hooks. If you're looking for a different experience when it comes to RPG's I really think you should give this one a try.

reviewText:
South Park: The Stick of Truth
So in, I forgot I was outside...


I have a problem, my problem is that I have little to nothing to say about this game...

Seriously, I've had a few games where I've had the same problem. For I feel that they manage to do wat they set out to do, so damn well. That I'm having to really strain myself to find something to gripe about.

...

I quess I could grumble a bit about the turn-based combat system, it feels a bit too standard, run-of-the-mill, copy-paste..
Several battles became too easy after I found the most optimal way around them, I believe (if my tally is to be believed) that I died the total of 4-times. During the total of.... 15-hours of gameplay that it took me to finish the game, I feel that's a rather positive ratio.

Whilst on the subject of combat, I'm not that impressed by the small amount of input lag I got when using a 360-pad. I've heard that it might have something to do with the game being locked at 30fps, it's a bit annoying when a perfectly timed block decides that it happened a split second too late and this happened way too many times to count.


The Audio-Visual style follows that of the TV-series, characters bob around imitating walking, the original cast does what it does best, everything looks like paper cut-outs.. The works.

The game has a lot of in-jokes and references to the TV-series and those who haven't seen much of the series might feel a bit left-out, but luckily being a keen fan of the series is not reguired.

There are collectables, yay... (HURRRGGGGGHHHH)

There are items to use, the same way as they do in other RPG's..

...


SIGH


...


Do you know how hard it is to find something to grumble about this game?...


You know what? I'l just give up now.. I'm going to Skeeters.

reviewText:
Bit late on this one but I'm bored so I'll do up a review to add to the near 20,000 other ones...

Pros
+ Hilarious [This is subjective but it's a funny game to me because it feels like old South Park, not new South Park]
+ Casual Gamplay [Even on Hard, so if you enjoy achievement whoring, this is a good thing]
+ Interactive Battle System [Timed hits like Super Mario RPG, I find this makes the game play less boring]
+ Old School South Park references for long time fans.
+ There's going to be a sequel [Fractured But Whole] so play this one first.
+ Holds your attention. [No grinding required to complete the game]
+ Jew class is OP as ♥♥♥♥. [If you enjoy playing as a Jew, this isn't a problem]
+ You get to visit Canada. [I'm Canadian, deal]

Cons
- Overpriced [Don't pay more than 30 dollars for this]
- Campaign is too short [Only 12-15 hours depending if you're going for 100%]
- Some achievements are bugged and require you to reload hours of game play to fix. [Still not patched either]
- Missible items which hinder achievements [Might have to restart entire campaign]
- Too easy [For Hardcore gamers, this game isn't even remotely challenging, too many exploitable builds]
- Some achievements are incredibly technical and can only be achieved in one or two spots in the entire game.
- Jew Class is OP [Class balance might be an issue for some people, not me, I like the Jew]
- Party system is lacking and feels tacked on. [Some character don't have enough utility and aren't worth using]

Final Thoughts
Hope that helps. A lot of people downvoted this game just due to price point which I feel is an unfair judgement of how good the game actually is, It's a great game, just not perfect. It's definitely not worth anything over 30 dollars and this is coming from someone who bought the 90 dollar collectors edition with the Cartman Wizard figure and then re-purchased it again on Steam for like 30 dollars again when it was on sale. It's not a 60 dollar title... it's not even a 40 dollar title... Just be smart with your purchase of this title and it'll be the best damn 20-30 dollars you've ever spent.

reviewText:
South Park: The Stick of Truth is a turned-based RPG. As the new kid in South Park, you get involved in a LARP opposing Cartman's Humans against Kyle's Elves, as the quiet little mountain town is place to events beyond what the kids anticipated.

Pros: This is a South Park fan's heaven. Fan service from across all seasons are fulfilled, as almost every characters from the show are either there or referenced at some level. Most loot are winks to episodes: a sarcastiball trophy, a shake weight, an Antonio Banderas love doll, an Okama Gamesphere, and hundreds more. If an episode reference wasn't in the loot, it's out there on display in a kid's room or closet. Every shop or radio play songs from the show (Chef, Jennifer Lopez, DVDA songs, you name it). The game smells of Matt Stone and Trey Parker's very-involved participation: the voice acting, the politically incorrect script and often down right disgusting language, the humor and how it critiques society. You feel like you're an actual character in South Park, forth wall breaks saved by the fact that you're playing a game about playing a game. Graphically, it looks exactly like the show, nothing groundbreaking but exactly what you'd expect.

Cons: The game is extremely basic, and the mechanics have little to no depth, save a few class skills. You equip 2 weapons and 3 pieces of armor with one or two customizable perk slots, some of which can be dyed assuming you found that dye color tube in-game, and some wigs or face paints that don't serve any purpose. The story is short, and extremely bare-bones. If not for the gameplay time and the exploration only fans will care about, you could fit the plot into a South Park movie. Skipping all that and the couple of optional sidequests you can finish the game in 10 hours (I bet many did it in less) with little replayability.

Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list

If you are not a fan of South Park, STAY AWAY! But if you are, this is an unquestionable must have. To the fan, it's a Season worth of content, jokes, running gags and nostalgia. South Park: The Stick of Truth is worth every dollar.

—————————————————————————
This was just my opinion.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

reviewText: Ok, there's a lot to cover on this game, but I'll just lay out the most glaring feature - it looks and feels exactly like you're part-taking in not just an episode, but in a whole interactive season of the show! The presentation is pitch perfect and all the characters are voiced by their original voice actors (mostly Trey Parker and Matt Stone). Perfect characters aside, the combat is another robust feature. It's easy to learn, but difficult to master; even if you've put hours in it. The story makes you feel both like an observer and a vital part of it at the same time, since you get to witness epic cutscenes and make crucial joices which influence the unfolding of the story. The humor, however, is what takes the ovations from the crowd, but beware - only long time South Park fans will get all the nods and references to various episodes, as well as feel more closely bound to classic characters. It's crude, offensive, with poor taste sometimes, but that cynical attitude makes South Park stand out from the crowd of mainstream TV flicks.  All and all, the game would be perfect if it had been a little more appealing to the newcomer audience, but I urge you to at least watch some episodes before you buy it, prefferably from the newer seasons.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
TL;DR  - Great game, some flaws, a game no South Park or RPG fan should miss.

Taking place immediately after the Game of Thrones inspired 244th through 247th episodes of the series in which the town's population have gone through the Blackest of Black Fridays, fighting to the death over random stuff on sale and in which game console the Boys should stake their futures.  The Stick of Truth is the Boys playing a full blown Live Action Role Playing Game in South Park even as sinister forces work against the unsuspecting town.  In comes the New Kid, and in keeping with the tropes set down by the genre, this silent protagonist must navigate the conflict between two warring factions as they seek to save the day.

Unfortunately the game feels like a bunch of it hit the cutting room floor, not for lack of inspiration, but for lack of funds.  The Stick of Truth suffers from being made by Obsidian and originally set to be published by the defunct THQ - this defuncting having occurred during the game's development and risking the fate of the game.  Obsidian representatives have on more than one occasion said their company nearly ran out of funds entirely while making this game.

Allow me to explain my gripes, and I apologize for the minor spoilers, I will try to keep it minimal.

Literally nothing you do will impact the game.  The two factions at war serve no purpose, they are a choice with no consequence.  You can obtain costumes which would imply allegiance to one or the other faction, but it has zero impact on the game.  You don't get a different power, you don't get a different weapon, you don't get a different hair cut even, you get sweet ♥♥♥♥ all for siding with either.

In most similarly designed games - the Fallout, Elder Scrolls, and Forgotten Realms series in particular, you will find that wearing the clothes of a faction impacts that faction's opinion of you and what you do and how you do it also factors into their responses.  Not so much here, again, nothing you do matters.  No quest will ensure the 5th graders will attack your enemy, reducing their combat effectiveness later in the game.  No dialogue will allow you to unlock a special companion.  Stealing from someone will not make people think less of you.

The game zips through story at a rather high speed, you go from arc to arc with little time to engage in what is happening.  Had the player a little more engagement with the events and characters, a branching story, this would not be a problem.  As it is however, you end up with a game that is boring to replay, most games of this type are awesome for replayability.

There are bugs, you will find yourself disappearing for no reason, and the camera focus moving off to the wrong part of the map.  You will need to restart the game to fix these sadly, but luckily they are not very common.

Oh lord, loading screens.  The game is not a graphically intense thing, it should not need so many.

Do not take these complaints as hate for the game, this is disappointment.  There could have been more to this, it could have been a clear Game of the Year, instead of just being one of the better games.

Combat is that of Super Mario RPG and it's kin, a very forgiving QTE-ish element is present to improve your attacks' and abilities' power.  Except for a lack in variety of combat, this is great.  And there are a few little full blown QTEs in game, but they also give plenty of reaction time and are clear with what to do.  This is easy enough that a child can play through the whole game without needing a hand.

The graphics are great, everything feels natural and looks like it belongs.  The art team should be given high jobs and blow fives.  The setting is wonderful, the town of South Park feels smaller than it should be, but what is there is alive and interesting.  I wish it was bigger to match the portrayal of the town from television, but we got a good chunk to play with.  The music, the voice acting, these are completely flawless.  They match the show in every way.  This all because the game was developed with close ties to South Park Studios who make the show.

If this game were not a South Park game, I would recommend it for everyone.  As it is however, anyone who is into RPGs and legally old enough to have a Steam account will have to do.

reviewText: Let's get this out of the way: If you don't enjoy south park as an animated show there's nothing here for you. But if you enjoy it from time to time or love it like I do, then by all means, buy and play the Stick of Truth. This is by far the most faithful adaptation of any TV show I've ever seen for a video game. It feels like you're playing a season of South Park. A good season at that. The game is a japanese-style RPG similar to Costume Quest and Mario & Luigi RPG series. There are a lot of great environment puzzles to get itens and avoid battles. The combat can feel a little too easy most of the time, but nothing that can ruin what is likely to be a great experience for you.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Ok, there's a lot to cover on this game, but I'll just lay out the most glaring feature - it looks and feels exactly like you're part-taking in not just an episode, but in a whole interactive season of the show! The presentation is pitch perfect and all the characters are voiced by their original voice actors (mostly Trey Parker and Matt Stone). Perfect characters aside, the combat is another robust feature. It's easy to learn, but difficult to master; even if you've put hours in it. The story makes you feel both like an observer and a vital part of it at the same time, since you get to witness epic cutscenes and make crucial joices which influence the unfolding of the story. The humor, however, is what takes the ovations from the crowd, but beware - only long time South Park fans will get all the nods and references to various episodes, as well as feel more closely bound to classic characters. It's crude, offensive, with poor taste sometimes, but that cynical attitude makes South Park stand out from the crowd of mainstream TV flicks.  All and all, the game would be perfect if it had been a little more appealing to the newcomer audience, but I urge you to at least watch some episodes before you buy it, prefferably from the newer seasons.

reviewText: South Park The Stick of Truth does a great job of making players feel like they are part of a South Park episode with the texture, atmosphere, and humor. Fans of the South Park series will love this game because of the refrences from the episodes of South Park layered in the game from the radio, characters, and much more. The gameplay is turn based with the player's charater and companions having to interact with thier desired move by timing mouse clicks or button presses at the right time. This mechanic makes the turn based gameplay a bit more interesting then choosing the desired attack by making players interact more in battle. It wouldn't be South Park without making fun of something or someone so the game makes fun of famous game titles like Skyrim with the use of 'dragon shout' by farting on players, which can be combined with your other attacks or used to interupt an enemy charging up their special attack. There are four classes to choose from one of them being the Jew class that can actaully be overpowered at times, but is a funny reference to one of the original characters from the south park series. The problems i have with this game are some of the achievements being difficult, some actions freezing up causing players to load from last save, and bad implemintation any replayability. The achievements are not only difficult but ridiculious because forgeting to talk to certain people to be on your friends list or missing a complete set of armor means having to restart the entire game to get back to the point you missed. The character freezing has happend only a few times but not manually saving before hand may cause people hours of backtracking as it only loads manual saves instead of auto saves. Replayability of this game is weaksauce as the end of the game is free roam with limited areas to go to and nothing really to do but walk around and finish up certain achievements. A new game plus would have been good here but I think the developers did this intentually so players would have to start over as a new character to get more hours out of this game. Overall this game is great even with some of the gripes mentioned. Fans and non fans of the South Park series will really enjoy this game unless you don't like crude humor then this might not be your game. I strongly recommend this game for the sheer fun and laughter it gives to players and hours of fun it has to offer. If you can get this game at a reduced price even better!

reviewText:
Only having a few hours in South Park I can already tell you that this game is AMAZING if you love the immature comedy that is South Park. What I wanted most out of this game is for it to bring me into the world of South Park and allow me to join in on the wacky rides that Kenny, Kyle, Stan, and Cartman get into. And that is exactly what is going on. I didn't expect the absurd amount of detail that you find throughout the world. It's not just do that quest do this quest move on, really take some time to explore you'll find countless amounts of subtle farts of hilarity.

What else that shocked me is how good the combat it. Let's face it turn based isn't for everyone, but I can't help but adore it when you get all these wacky weapons and skills. It also takes some strategy to get it right, sometimes you might not simpily have the right companions or maybe you're too undergeared or maybe you just have bad reaction time and missed a few blocks that killed you. Overall the RPG aspect of this game is amazing as well.

As a game reviewer on Youtube for over two years now I've seen my fair share of awesome and equally ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games. I don't know what it is about South Park: The Stick of Truth but it's easily one of my most cherished additions to my collection.


I HIGHLY suggest you buy the game and experience the game first hand but if you don't have the funding or simily prefer playthroughs I have started one on my channel and you're more than welcome to join me on my adventure. But please consider buying this game and supporting the wonderful people that took the time to make this.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EWQd5lMQmGw

reviewText: I really enjoyed this game!  Combat is pretty easy, at least if you have a min/max mentality when it comes to choosing companions, gear, and spells.  Fortunately, there's just enough combat in the game to balance out the exploration aspect without become too overly boring by the end of the game (for South Park fans, at least).  The game does a super job of recreating all the landmarks of the TV show and the voice acting is exactly what a fan would hope for.  I do get a little bit of screen tearing that I haven't been able to get rid of, but it's not enough of a problem to sour the game for me.  Stick of Truth features superb controller support and I appreciated being able to earn Steam achievements and play without launching UPlay even though this is an Ubisoft game.  This is an easy game to recommend for South Park fans.

reviewText:
As for the South Park, and Paper Mario fan I am, I have had alot of fun playing this game. Surely it's not the lengthiest RPG (with a barely 15 hour long gameplay time), and while the combat is rather tame with the lack of depth, balance and variety, as some spells or attacks are more ineffective than others, while you'll find some devastating attacks which will prevent you from varying the way you play, but for it's short storymode it should keep you entertained until you've played through all the sidequests and the main story.

As for a South Park game, it truly feels like you're watching an actual South Park episode, or even a whole season, at the same time while playing.

Also, important mention is how the game plays alot like Paper Mario, with ''active turnbased combat'', by which I mean every move you perform requires you to either tap a button, or time a button pressing in order to successfully perform an action.
The game also has partners, which all have their own unique abillities and spells, like such as Butters's Professor Chaos transformation (which by the way, is my favourite pick).

However, if you have no interest for South Park, or even have a certain disgust for it, you won't be missing out at all if you're not going to buy it. A must have for a South Park fan however.

8/10

reviewText:
The Stick of Truth is at its best when it straddles the incredible - but true - ability of a bunch of kids to bring a game of pretend to extreme heights of seriousness, with limited stakes appearing huge.
It's at its best when it is about play.

In these phases, the succinct turn-based combat, the battleground navigation, the limited character interaction and shape of the world exist as a masterful and coherent whole. They generate this fantastic flow that - in one trick - justify the game pretense while engaging the player in it, epic battle throughout fake taverns and parental curfew taken in strides.

When the world of 'normal' adult gets involved or when the game brings back some of the series lore along with stalwart tropes, it is far less successful: the veil of pretend falls and what's left is a giddy but dull self-awareness that highlights the least  flattering parts of the game structure.

Chief of these is the turn based combat and its place in the progression: it allows for tedious conservatism (same moves all the time) instead of encouraging experimentation with your equipment and with your buddies during encounters. In the same way, the block system has very unreliable sign and feedback; which makes it difficult to use.

Beside that, your mileage may vary: South Park has built several facets during its run and I don't care for the scat humor from the first seasons or the easy lampooning of popular culture icons that recent years have brought.

Some people do and I expect they'll enjoy the game to through and through. I couldn't because what really interests me is the writers harsh tackling of controversial topics or of the darker aspects of the  logic and ecosystem that you'll find in a pack of kids. There's a significant amount of that (along with a nearly invisible touch of social commentary), but the scat and the pop-ref ARE what the last two thirds of the game ride on.

And I can't support that choice: it makes the game less of a beast of its own - self contained, designed for the experience - and makes it rely on a bunch of crutches that are offputtingly obvious and ultimately unnecessary.

The music is awesome though.

This will surely be one of the best games of 2014. People may think that is just an overpriced game about fart jokes, but it's way better than that.

In this epic game, we play as the New Kid, after he and his parents move to South Park, a quiet little mountain town. But there is a reason for this change. The kid has a power, for wich he is wanted by the goverment.

reviewText:
Alright 5 hours into the game (including time wasted between laughter, exploration, and being outright stuck), it's been pretty reminiscent as well as enjoyful. A lot of references, and definitely the humor most people recognize the series as being known for.

Pros:
- Customization (character, appearance, stats, abilities)
- Interactivity (Really does feel like an RPG game, in both fights and exploration of the overworld.)
- The same stupid (but laughable) comedy this series has been known for.

Cons:
- Known bugs that can interrupt your playthrough (Experienced one such bug when learning my first Magic spell. I had to reload a checkpoint about 1 minute before the tutorial).
- Instructions can sometimes be unclear of where to go next, or interactable items can be difficult to notice (This may not apply to all people. I was stuck twice for about 10 minutes each unsure of what to do next.).
- Even for the humor and gameplay (Let's be serious, this was not a game for a high graphics expectation), compared to other games available now at similar or lower prices, I say it is not worth the FULL $60. It's worth a good chunk of that in my opinion (Like $30-$40), but not the full $60.

Overall: Worth getting if you see it on sale. It's a good time filler when I want to play a game on my own, that a 3-year old laptop can still run at perfect frames.

reviewText:
South Park™: The Stick of Truth™ is one of the few TV series based games out there that totally excels at both storytelling and gameplay. It feels like a 15 hour long (well, a little less for you if you don't do sidequests, level up or just walk around) episode.

It has everything you can expect from South Park and more. It parodies almost all RPG games ever created in such an hilarious way, because remember, it IS South Park after all.

Having explicit +18 content like it should, the PC version doesn't have any censorship which is great because censoring South Park is missing the point of it. Also, it borders the riddiculous so many times it's amazing how they managed to put this whole story together while keeping its humour fresh.

On the technical side, a few bugs and glitches here and there that hopefully will be fixed with later patches. Nothing too serious, only a few character flickers in the cinematics and sometimes the music won't play, but nothing that breaks the game in any way (maybe some of the immersion, but that being said, reloading the last checkpoint usually helped).

Now, to the most important part on where you should or not buy the game: IS IT WORTH THE $60 PRICETAG? No. Not at all. I expect playing it only once more right now and maybe replaying it at a later date ocassionally just for the laughs. No multiplayer because remember this is a turn based RPG and we wouldn't have it any other way, but that removes a lot from the replayability value and thus the pricetag should be lower. 30 bucks is about right, 1.50 an hour. Maybe even less, like 15 bucks.

But that shouldn't stop me from recommending this anyway. Because this game is awesome. It feels like a game. It IS a game. And also a 15 hour long South Park episode. And both are worth the time and the cash to enjoy.

I hope they release some DLC with an expansion on the story or something because it still has room for more content.
