reviewText:
Hmm what can i say about this game.

Its south park, but also its a role playing game set in the south universe.

It took a while for the developers of this game to release it, after having the studio that was making it kind of get split up and sold.  The creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone had a huge hand in helping make this game become a reality.  They of course do most of hte voice work, but also it seams they had a say in how the game characters should move and feel when you play.

When you start this game you get treated to a great introduction that you will say to yourself...this is definately south park.  All the way down to when you create your character and move them around it will look like a south park cartoon.

This game impressed me alot, by the care and work done on it.  The humor is outstanding well at least to those that like the south park genre and I am sure even non-fans and those who dont know what south park is will like this title.

Among other things there is a bit of fan service at places....like being able to see inside for example cartman's closet and see all those things that where from differing eppisodes of the TV show.

I like this game and i do recommend at least a try by anyone who has the money and time to play it.

Combat like other RPG games is kind of turn based at times.....but the interesting part is that they give you ques to do things during this combat...instead of actual turns.

The rest fo the game features puzzles and over area exploration.  Included inthe game is also the silly internal menu whihc they took the time to make it meaningful.  What i mean by this is....you use a cell phone to manage your equipment and friends and things....the funny part is...there is an in game social network where you can see differing things your friends say about each other or things that you do or dont do.

All in all I would say this game would delight everyone who tries it.

However I am not sure if anyone should let their children of too young an age play this one....due to the fact it does have violence and some harsh language.

reviewText:
Before reading my review further, do note these:
• I am a very hardcore South Park fan, not just for the humour, but for the valuable life lessons it taught me for so many years.
• This review is not a fanboy one, despite my feelings and personal thoughts, i try to be impartial when it comes to giving an opinion.
• I am not a very big fan of RPG games, it's not my 'main genre', maybe because i am not that nerdy (don't feel offended, please, or.. if you do, i can give you some butter to let it sink). Mostly i do not like RPGs because many of them have a huge imbalance between action, atmosphere, and a good story, but i do appreciate RPGs that deserve it.

I wished this for a long time now, my girlfriend bought it since it was my name day. I did not wish this as a 'game', i thought it might be pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥, i just wanted it for the humour and because it's South Park.
I loved it so much that i played it 12 hours since she got it for me, with only 3 breaks (kinda small), i know, i know, it's kinda alot.
I can't talk much about the story, we all know it, i can tell you about it's moral tho, it's about how kids nowadays just stay on facebook all day, and refuse to socialize and play outside, you need to recruite kids to play with, but most of them are 'busy', you are one of the few kids that choose to turn a simple normal stick, into a 'supreme weapon' that can 'control the universe', so basically, it's an RPG in which you are playing an RPG. You and the other kids playing 'The Stick of Truth' had built a world separate from the real world in which kids nowadays don't play anymore, and don't do anything creatively.
I won't change a single thing in the story, it's so damn perfect, it has that South Park feeling, with alot of humour, that teaches you one more important thing.

The game itself was done great, the atmosphere is there, you can feel it, you can feel that you are indeed a kid in South Park, Colorado.
There might be few minor glitches, you usually can get past them easily, not a big deal.
When i finished it, i felt like cryng, i enjoyed every ♥♥♥♥ing second of it!


I would love an open-world South Park MMORPG, i will give you all my monies.
PS: If you never watched South Park, i suggest you see the whole show from the beginning, there are many things you might not understand if you never watched it.

reviewText:
Well well well... not bad. Not bad at all. The South Park (SP) guys have really done it. They have managed to make a game that looks and plays like a SP episode. The characters are there, the humour is there, the music is there and ofc the raunchiness is there. If you are into SP you will not be disappointed.

So, you are the new kid - in my case a black Jewish kid with freckles and purple hair - and you just moved into SP. It is your mission to make friends, beat up elves and bums, loot what you can and deal with a fair deal of anal probing. Your charter is customizable up to the balls (no pun intended, you can have balls on your chin) with various clothes, weapons, haircuts, glasses etc. As in most rpg-s you get levels from fighting and questing and upon levelling up your stats go up (you can’t pick which stats) and you unlock more abilities (you can choose perks and you gain magic spells and special abilities that level up). The battle is turn based, but has a quick time event system built into it every step of the way. Oddly enough, I really did not not like it! In fact, the game is pretty solid all around. It’s a good RPG.

True RPG fans will ofc be missing the ability to assign your str/agi/int etc and maybe they will expect a larger variety of skills and especially magic (8h in, I find the magic/fart system to be perhaps the most disappointing part of it, but still ok) but you do get to shape how you do your damage so you feel in control all the time.

The game is well paced, there is always something for you to do, the game world is easy to travel /a bit small maybe even/ so you don’t waste time just travelling. New areas of the world open up as you gain new abilities giving you reasons to go back to places you have visited already.

If you can take the SP humour, you will never have a dull moment and you will be adventuring with smile on your face the whole time.  This game is fab aside from the lacklustre magic system.

9/10

reviewText:
Stick of Truth's a surprisingly engrossing RPG, and a good entry point to the genre for South Park fans.

It's clearly a console game, with limited options and no modding ability, fairly low difficulty level, and plays very well on a gamepad. And it's not particularly long for an RPG - you can get through the meat of it in around 16 hours without rushing.

However, it's great fun. You can explore the entire town of South Park, sifting through shops and houses for items, and as you progress through the main story, you'll unlock new abilities that allow you to reach new areas of familiar locations. Levelling happens very frequently, via two separate systems - one skill tree is unlocked by amassing 'friends' on South Park's pseudo-Facebook (accomplished by completing quests or exploring), and the other is unlocked by gaining XP from combat.

Combat happens very often, whether you're just wandering round the town or engaging in quests. It's turn-based, with you controlling an ally (such as Kenny or Butters) as well as your own character. There are several different damage types, which can multiply each other (for example, if you set an enemy on fire, then farting on them will cause much more damage). Weapons range from throwable tampons to ninja stars to Cartman's respect-mah-authoritah" truncheon

reviewText:
♥♥♥♥ing amazing! Lads 'n lassies who love South park show: You must own this game. It's so rare we see a great game licenesed based. What to say about this game?

Well imagenie that one day, you became a SP charecter, right after Season1 7 finale; Kids still playing Dungeon and Dragons combined with Game of Thrones, adults are just same dumbarses they usually are in show, and ones again a great danger rise (or should i say decent) upon quiet little mountien town. Telling more -- would be revealing spoilers, and that would be a crime. I will just say that: Playing Stick of Truth is like watching another 3-5 episodes of South park.

There are a lot of content for fans, easter eggs here and there, references, infamous satire.

Gameplay itself is solid and will keep you interteined. A mix between JRPG and WRPG, made surprisingly well. Classes, diffrent tactics and combat moves, partners, gear and so on. Nothing that ye haven't seen before or any inovations. But it works.

The game have flows; It's short (even if you will go crazy and complete all side quests), level cap issue, and if you are not SP fan... you will not get this game. A minor issues here and there, but overall, this is a good game by itself and masterpiece fans deserve!

So, if you one of those SP fans; gear up, buy a few Cheesy Puffs, tell kitty to go away and remove children and easy to offend people from the monitor. Because South park is a show that no one suppose to watch and game should not be played. Got the idea?

reviewText: South Park: The Stick of Truth is finally released after a couple delays. All I can say after playing this game sometime is that it's truly a MUST have for all South Park fans out there! South Park: The Stick of Truth's got to be one of the funniest games I've ever played. It's designed to make you feel like you're watching a regular episode of the show which they have suceeded to do. You can be sure the show's famous childish, religion hating, poop humour's in the game as well. As an RPG- and longtime fan of the show I must say the game is excellent and funny as hell. I've started crying from laughter several times. Nonetheless, this game's genius and if you're either a fan of the show or you enjoy playing RPG games (even though this game's not a serious one) this is definitely a game for you!

reviewText:
This game is not a shabby game adaption of a succesful franchice that completely fails like any other game adaption. This is a game that was written, designed and developed by the original South Park creators. Including original voices and all the trademark (dark) humor the TV show has become famous for.

Because of this, South Park: The Stick of Truth feels like you are watching a feature length South Park movie. Everything is just there. The characters are spot on. The voices are spot on and the storyline is traditionally 'wtf am I watching' good/fun. Even when you're actively controlling your character the world around you feels 'real'.

You play as 'the new kid' who's parents moved to South Park after some incident involving you. And as you go out to make friends you run into the South Park cast who are in the middle of a very very serious role playing game involving humans vs the elves. The role playing game mechanics the children have made up is translated into gameplay mechanics. Foods are health potions, energy drinks are power potions and anything that gives you serious gas are mana potions.

The gameplay is fairly fun, though also fairly limited. You are free to explore South Park as much as you wish and interact with its inhabitants. Meanwhile you can raid their houses and garages for items and potions without consequence. The world is fairly interactable. Often you are able to shoot things or break things outside of combat. Sometimes leading to taking out enemies before a fight actually starts. This is a good thing because the fights tend to get boring fast.

Fighting occurs when enemies tag you during exploration. You can also tag them first, whoever lands the first blow gets to take the first turn during the combat phase. The combat mechanics themselves center around turn based combat. You and one compantion have to battle up to six enemies at a time. During a turn you may consume an item to give you a bonus and perform one attack. When all enemies are defeated the fight is won and you go back to exploration.

The fighting mechanics work and are fun. But they are only fun for so long. Especially in the beginning you are regularly jumped by enemies who force you into a fight. For me this started to get annoying because I just wanted to get to my next objective, not do all kinds of random fighting. Later in the game this becomes increasingly frustrating because fights become more frequent and enemies become harder to beat and/or appear in larger numbers.

The actual attacks are also confusing. There is a whole range of buttons and combos to use various attacks, but none of them seem to make any sense. One sword requires a left click, another sword requires a right click. The 'spells' are taught to you through a complicated 'find the right frequency' tutorial but this is never applied again during actual fights. Blocking enemies can get tedious and frustrating. The game will indicate when you need to block, but this turns out to be highly inaccurate. There is also the use of shields and armor which are apparently two different things but are never properly explained. A lot of fighting mechanics are just thrown at you and you are left to figure out how they work on your own.

All in all this is a very good game. True to the TV show and fairly ok gameplay to boot. But this being South Park, be prepared for some extremely weird and grotesque scenes. From visuals of anal probing to Nazi zombie fetuses (including swastikas) that spew various Adolf Hitler soundbites at you. If you think you know what to expect from South Park, be prepared to see them push the limits of the acceptable.

Recommended to get this game on or off sale. It's worth full price if you ask me.

reviewText: As a dedicated South Park fan, I can truly say this is the game any South Park fan has been waiting for. It pays the perfect amount of tribute to classic and new episodes alike while creating an experience and story that is unique, much like any other thing Trey and Matt have produced. The gameplay is indeed simple, a classic turn-based RPG, but still incredibly fun. Everything from your equipment to your abilities and enemies are truly fantastically designed to fit right into the South Park universe, and there are a lot of hilarious enemies and boss battles that all seem to keep the game different as you continue to play through it. While I haven't beaten the game just yet, I have heard it is a bit on the short side, but with the great mix of fun gameplay, hilarious comedy, amazing story-telling by Matt and Trey(as usual), I think it's well worth the price tag. Plus the town of South Park is chock full of fun places to explore with even the junk" items you find lying around being little easter eggs for both longtime and newer fans of the show. I totally recommend this game for any fans of the show
date: or even anyone who is just curious what it's all about
recommended: as it is a perfect snapshot of the genious comedic minds of Matt Stone and Trey Parker."

You can beat the entire game in under a day so try to limit yourself to a couple hours at a time to maximze playtime. If you are a South Park fan you will enjoy the game.

reviewText:
On the positive side:

+Looks, sounds and feels just like the TV show.
+Hilarious and insane. No spoilers, but if you decide to play this game, be prepared to see some epic ♥♥♥♥.
+An open world with a main quest and numerous side quests
+Almost every character from South Park makes an appearance, or is at least mentioned - even single episode characters like Damien, Gazunga and the Woodland Christmas Critters.
+A multitude of outfits and a nice stockpile of weapons
+Makes fun of many video game cliches

And on the negative side:

-No Russell Crowe :(  (maybe there'll be a 'Fighting Around the World' DLC?)
-The main quest is completely linear and kind of shortish.
-The level cap is rather low. In fact, it's so low, you're sure to hit it before you finish the MQ even if you're avoiding all of the side ones.

Overall: You probably heard this 100 times before, but if you're a fan of the show, or are simply looking for a game that doesn't treat itself too seriously, you'll (probably) love The Stick of Truth.
Protip - if the Steam price is too steep for you, you'll probably get a better deal at your local retailer. I did.

reviewText:
Absolutely loved my time with this game. A single play through took about 18 hours.

Being able to enjoy southpark is a lynchpin to recommending this game and if you do you'll have a great time. I haven't actually watched the show in many years but I felt like I was playing an episode and had a blast.

The gameplay itself is fairly easy even on the hardest difficulty and calls back to the likes of paper mario. I enjoyed it enough to start another play through with a different one of the 4 available classes, however at it's core it doesn't have much replayability.

It's abolustely wonderful to know this game exists and is good, it's an example that we can indeed have nice things.

reviewText:
Genuine south park experience. A bit over-hyped and hard to avoid spoilers. Best served with no previous review consumption.

Game mechanics are OK, although the end game is driven by story not the mechanics since you can easily become a bit overpowered and each battle can be won by the same moves over and over again, accordingly the beginning of the game is a bit slow paste and story begins to shine after maybe 6 hours (or less) of game play depending on how active you'll be with the exploring and side quests.

Side quest count is really low and most of them can be completed and accessed early on in the game. There's little value for playing it few times and content will cover around 12 hours.

When it comes to censored scenes by Ubisoft - realistically there was just two scenes where I though that it could't be shown on TV. If you think otherwise - watch south park few seasons back. Again, it's bit over-talked and over-hyped, it's not that bad and could go further in some cases.

All in all - it's a fun trip for the south park fans and good standing grounds for future releases. Regards the price - I would wait for a sale.

reviewText:
South Park the stick of truth is a love letter to fans of the show. While playing the game you feel like you’re watching an entire season of South Park which stars you. The game’s presentation is outstanding from the voice acting, to the animation style, to the music. The game is laugh out loud funny. However, if you’re easily offended it’s best to stay clear. The humor is shocking, crude, and insulting the way it’s meant to be.

As far as gameplay goes it’s a turn based RPG like super Mario All-stars where you have to time your attacks and blocks with a button press. There are four classes to choose from expect the standard three classes (fighter, mage, thief) and the south park exclusive Jew class. The actual RPG elements are pretty simple but with the south park flair. For example, all the health potions and consumables are items from the show like cheesy poofs. There is also some small customization you can do with weapon and armor patches that give certain stats. While the RPG elements are light it’s simply a joy just to see the south park flair on certain attacks and summons. For example, you can summon Jesus to do your bidding, turn into professor Chaos to wreck your enemies, or watch how Cartman does a fire attack.

There are a ton of references and hidden Easter eggs in this game. Almost every major character from the show makes an appearance in some way. It was simply fun just exploring the town and seeing what people had in their houses.
The one downside is that the game is a little on the short side. It’s about 15 hours long if you do all the side quests as well. However, there is no grinding in this game to fill the time. Not once while I was playing did I get bored.

If you’re a fan of the show definitely pick this game up. It’s worth your time and your money. The creators of South Park and Obsidian Entertainment have possibly made the best licensed game besides the excellent Batman Arkham games.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Obsidian outdid themselves. This game is spectacular. It's very true to the show, the subtleties are great. There's callbacks to previous episodes as far back as season 1. As an RPG, the combat is fantastic, loot is awesome, it's just an all around solid game. I disagree that there's no replayability. I have no problem blowing through this again. I paid full price and I'm getting my money's worth. Absolutely no regrets. THIS, this is how video game adaptations of TV shows or movies need to be handled.\n\nStick of Truth is legit. It's absolutely worth the asking price.

reviewText: My only real gripe with the game is that it is 60 dollars currently, that being said the game has kept me busy for about 12 hours at this time and I plan on playing it a lot more to try different classes and make different decisions. It is a SouthPark RPG and it holds nothing back when it comes to humor or attention to detail, it's an RPG making fun of RPG's and yet it's more enjoyable than a lot of RPG's that have come out in recent years. I have no regrets on buying it and hope they develop more content for it in the future

reviewText: The Stick of Truth was fun and funny. There's a decent sized quest, around 17hrs to finish everything.  The game reminds me of the fantastic Super Mario RPG series.  The game is set in a cartoon world and has simple yet engaging battle mechanics and there's some solid humor to the game. However, I have a feeling this game will not be fondly remembered in the years to come. A lot of the jokes are rehashes and sometimes not even really jokes, but more just references to various different OLD episodes. There are some really funny new villains to battle. The game is really easy. After the first real boss battle, there wasn't any challenge to any of the battles afterwards. The character becomes so over powered.  Another thing that annoyed me was something that's been dragging the show down too is the product placement. A certain famous diarrheatorium is prominently featured in the plot and it's weak that I'm paying out money just be shown commercials. The game is rough around the edges, but there's obviously a lot of talent that went into making the game, but the sense I come away with strongest from the game is that it just feels like wasted potential. It could've been great and it ended up decent.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EiUFaZIi5O0&list=PL0E56219EE956754E

South Park: The Stick of Truth: It’s a very rare thing to see licenses from television shows or movies be made into a videogame and actually turn out to be a great game. South Park: The Stick of Truth is one of those rare occasions. A great role-playing game made by Obsidian Entertainment (creators of Fallout: New Vegas) along with the creators of South Park (who also do a lot of the voice acting) to create a funny and simple game in which to celebrate the world of South Park and also to give fans something to enjoy for years to come. While relatively short by most role-playing game standards, lasting between 15-18 hours, The Stick of Truth gives enough variety and plenty of humor to make it an easily enjoyable experience and worth the asking price. Everything in the game is wholly belonging to South Park, it has songs from episodes dotted throughout the game, voice actors make a return to voice their respective characters and everything feels like South Park. Visuals also feel directly translated from the show, the game feels like a very long episode of the show. Controls are simple and easy to learn, the game overall is pretty easy with only a few enemies posing a decent challenge so you won’t feel very much pressure from the combat portion of the game. The only real detriment to South Park: The Stick of Truth is the fact that it is everything South Park. While I personally find the game to be funny and enjoy the jokes, it is easy to see how this game can turn away those who aren’t huge fans or hate the humor that South Park has and there isn’t an amazing enough role-playing game here to win those on the fence about South Park over. The other minor gripe with the game is the controls when using the mouse and keyboards. Some of the abilities didn’t feel like they responded as well when using their respective keys versus a controller. I also experience a few glitches such as Jimmy not getting out of his stuttering loop and some minor glitches of my character flickering in and out of a scene during a cinematic.

Overall I enjoyed my time with South Park: The Stick of Truth, there is a fun role-playing game here along with the great humor of South Park. Those who won’t enjoy this game are those who are going to be offended by what is displayed in the game or just don’t enjoy the humor of South Park. If you are middle of the ground and don’t mind the humor the role-playing game beneath may not be enough to warrant a full $60.00 USD price tag.

-Thumbs Up from Royial

Video Review: www.youtube.com/user/RoyialNetwork

reviewText: South Park: The Stick of Truth is finally released after a couple delays. All I can say after playing this game sometime is that it's truly a MUST have for all South Park fans out there! South Park: The Stick of Truth's got to be one of the funniest games I've ever played. It's designed to make you feel like you're watching a regular episode of the show which they have suceeded to do. You can be sure the show's famous childish, religion hating, poop humour's in the game as well. As an RPG- and longtime fan of the show I must say the game is excellent and funny as hell. I've started crying from laughter several times. Nonetheless, this game's genius and if you're either a fan of the show or you enjoy playing RPG games (even though this game's not a serious one) this is definitely a game for you!

reviewText:
The main thing to know about this game is it is very faithful to the TV show as a whole, though that should be a given since the game's story was written by South Park's creators. It is pretty much inserting yourself into the world of South Park, interacting with the world and its characters in fun and humorous ways.

The gameplay itself isn't that bad either, anyone familar with the battle systems of games like Paper Mario will adapt quick to this and its easy enough to pick up even if you haven't. However one thing I will criticise the game for is the lack of depth for character progression, your max level caps out at 15 and given how much you can progress your abilities, a max level of 25 I feel would have been better suited.

Aside from that, there are a lot of weird and wonderful weapons that you can acquire during the game from Darts to dodgeballs to vibrating ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Also many costume pieces can be found, each with their own passives attached such as extra armor or a boost in fire damage.

These pieces can be customised further through the use of 'Strap-ons' to give extra benefits like causing bleeding, giving more armor and even recovering hp and pp on perfect attacks.

The game provides choices in the game but really they do little to effect the game's story, just more something you will do for achievements and choosing who you will fight later on until a point where the two sides merge.

Also hope you like references, cause the game is full of them from the show such as the 30 Chimpokomon you can collect during the course of the game to well known references from the show.

As for those who will be affected by the censorship the game's makers put in, I found they don't really do much to spoil anything, just two minigames though I think some audio dialogue in the second half of the game (least in the Australian version) is cut out as well, or just my sound card ♥♥♥♥ing sucks, either or which.

All in all it's a solid rpg for those interested and also a game for diehard fans of South Park to enjoy, however I would suggest avoiding it if you are the sort of person easily offended by the style of crude humor shows like South Park provide.

reviewText:
This happens if you get the makers of South Park and the developers of Fallout create a game similar to Paper Mario gameplay in the South Park universe, with LoTR theme and references from other fantasy games.

Never laughed this much in a while. And I couldn't put the controller down. Played 13 hours within a day and completed the main story plus some exploring and a bit of side quests with 50% achievements completion. Doing all the side quests would probably take you 30+ hours.

Not much replay value but you may need to do another run (with guides/walk through) if you want to perfect the achievements.

Almost perfect game. It just feels too short for an RPG game.

Overall 9/10

reviewText:
First off, let me start by saying this game is FANTASTIC. I'm not a huge turn based RPG player, but I picked up the game with skepticism because I'd heard good things about it and it's South Park.

The game is funny and engaging. It has a lot to do and I found myself spending entire afternoons and evenings playing this game (which I don't do very often). As I walked around South Park doing side quests I found myself laughing at the dialogue of people I passed by or my buddy when I did certain things or went certain places. There are so many Easter Eggs in this game that you can find while walking around looting (Butters' Creamy Goo and Chinpokomon to name a couple) and a lot of them are cleverly placed.

South Park: The Stick of Truth is a fantastic turn-based RPG and doesn't disappoint. The game feels like a very long episode of South Park and it actually looks like one too. I can recommend this to people who have only seen the show a few times and you'll still love it to death. 10/10.

reviewText:
This is the must-have game for all South Park fans. The entire town of South Park is finally mapped out in detail; this matched with great dialogue, a superb plot and fantastic gameplay. Some of the content is a bit grim and or absurd/perhaps vulgar; but I guess that’s what you expect for a game from Trey Parker and Matt Stone.

It’s somewhat surprising all the content which is crammed into the game, with the added bonus of it being easily re-playable. You have: The great battle between Men and Elves. The on-going mysterious tale of The New Kid. Strange happenings regarding abductions! This game has this and so much more without pulling too much focus from the main plot.

8.9/10. I think it’s a definite Buy. I’d happily (and eagerly) await for another.

reviewText: I have to say I was really impressed by this game, picked it up in the Christmas sale for about half price and went into it more or less blind, not knowing what to expect other than it being South Park in a video game. reviewText:
South Park the stick of truth is a love letter to fans of the show. While playing the game you feel like you’re watching an entire season of South Park which stars you. The game’s presentation is outstanding from the voice acting, to the animation style, to the music. The game is laugh out loud funny. However, if you’re easily offended it’s best to stay clear. The humor is shocking, crude, and insulting the way it’s meant to be.

As far as gameplay goes it’s a turn based RPG like super Mario All-stars where you have to time your attacks and blocks with a button press. There are four classes to choose from expect the standard three classes (fighter, mage, thief) and the south park exclusive Jew class. The actual RPG elements are pretty simple but with the south park flair. For example, all the health potions and consumables are items from the show like cheesy poofs. There is also some small customization you can do with weapon and armor patches that give certain stats. While the RPG elements are light it’s simply a joy just to see the south park flair on certain attacks and summons. For example, you can summon Jesus to do your bidding, turn into professor Chaos to wreck your enemies, or watch how Cartman does a fire attack.

There are a ton of references and hidden Easter eggs in this game. Almost every major character from the show makes an appearance in some way. It was simply fun just exploring the town and seeing what people had in their houses.
The one downside is that the game is a little on the short side. It’s about 15 hours long if you do all the side quests as well. However, there is no grinding in this game to fill the time. Not once while I was playing did I get bored.

If you’re a fan of the show definitely pick this game up. It’s worth your time and your money. The creators of South Park and Obsidian Entertainment have possibly made the best licensed game besides the excellent Batman Arkham games.

reviewText: Obsidian outdid themselves. This game is spectacular. It's very true to the show, the subtleties are great. There's callbacks to previous episodes as far back as season 1. reviewText: The Stick of Truth was fun and funny. There's a decent sized quest, around 17hrs to finish everything.  The game reminds me of the fantastic Super Mario RPG series.  The game is set in a cartoon world and has simple yet engaging battle mechanics and there's some solid humor to the game. However, I have a feeling this game will not be fondly remembered in the years to come. A lot of the jokes are rehashes and sometimes not even really jokes, but more just references to various different OLD episodes. There are some really funny new villains to battle. The game is really easy. After the first real boss battle, there wasn't any challenge to any of the battles afterwards. The character becomes so over powered.  Another thing that annoyed me was something that's been dragging the show down too is the product placement. A certain famous diarrheatorium is prominently featured in the plot and it's weak that I'm paying out money just be shown commercials. The game is rough around the edges, but there's obviously a lot of talent that went into making the game, but the sense I come away with strongest from the game is that it just feels like wasted potential. It could've been great and it ended up decent.

reviewText:
On the positive side:

+Looks, sounds and feels just like the TV show.
+Hilarious and insane. No spoilers, but if you decide to play this game, be prepared to see some epic ♥♥♥♥.
+An open world with a main quest and numerous side quests
+Almost every character from South Park makes an appearance, or is at least mentioned - even single episode characters like Damien, Gazunga and the Woodland Christmas Critters.
+A multitude of outfits and a nice stockpile of weapons
+Makes fun of many video game cliches

And on the negative side:

-No Russell Crowe :(  (maybe there'll be a 'Fighting Around the World' DLC?)
-The main quest is completely linear and kind of shortish.
-The level cap is rather low. In fact, it's so low, you're sure to hit it before you finish the MQ even if you're avoiding all of the side ones.

Overall: You probably heard this 100 times before, but if you're a fan of the show, or are simply looking for a game that doesn't treat itself too seriously, you'll (probably) love The Stick of Truth.
Protip - if the Steam price is too steep for you, you'll probably get a better deal at your local retailer. I did.

reviewText:
Gameplay: 8/10
The stick of truth is played within a turn based combat system in which you play as a party of two with each character you pair with having different abilities that can help you in combat. Your own character will have abilities dependent on the class you choose. The combat is simple and not at all complex so is easy for those not used to the genre however can become quite repetitive due to limited commands.
Graphics: 9/10
Although the graphics in itself isnt overly impressive or demanding the way in which the stick of truth presents itself is great as it is show in a 2d view within a 3d space and looks and feels much like you're in the TV show, everything looks nice and exactly like shown in the show which is great for fans of the series.
Story: 9/10
The story is like a massive episode of South Park, very funny and extremely rude which those who watch South Park are expecting. Matt Stone and Trey Parker helped out with the story of the game aswell as giving the voices from the show so works perfectly, Only wish it was longer.
OVERALL: 9/10

Having read the reviews, but played none of the earlier South Park games, I went into Stick of Truth expecting a marginally above-average game that I'd have a 50/50 chance of hitting delete local content" on during the first hour.
What I actually found was:
1/ A legitimately funny game - funnier than a good 60% of South Park proper;
2/ Turn-based combat I not only enjoyed
date: but took seriously and implemented strategically;\n3/ A coherent story that held my interest from beginning to end.\nThe Stick of Truth is definately not the sort of game I've historically sought out
recommended: or enjoyed. However I find it hard to find any fault with this game
hoursPlayed: and without reservation recommend it to anyone that's ever got a laugh from a South Park episode."

reviewText:
Okay, so, if you are a South Park fan, this *review thingie* or whatever this is (but definitely not a review) will be very short: BUY IT. YOU'LL LOVE EVERY SECOND OF THIS GAME.

You also wanna know why? Well, okay... dialogues are AWESOME, the story is practically a huge interactive episode of South Park, it's full of easter eggs, references and little details about all the things you loved most in the show. I really don't want to spoiler anything but trust me, it's great. Gameplay wise The Stick of Truth is a fairly simple JRPG, if I had to say something I didn't like is that the game is a little too easy, so you don't have time to use all the party members unless you farm certain enemies at a particular point of the game. But let's be honest, you don't play a South Park game for the RPG mechanics (which aren't bad by the way, the game is fun to play), you play it for the story and the dialogues, and those things are GREAT.

A lot of achievements, collectibles, excellent player customization, good replayability, the whole package. Thumbs up.

reviewText:
First off, let me start by saying this game is FANTASTIC. I'm not a huge turn based RPG player, but I picked up the game with skepticism because I'd heard good things about it and it's South Park.

The game is funny and engaging. It has a lot to do and I found myself spending entire afternoons and evenings playing this game (which I don't do very often). As I walked around South Park doing side quests I found myself laughing at the dialogue of people I passed by or my buddy when I did certain things or went certain places. There are so many Easter Eggs in this game that you can find while walking around looting (Butters' Creamy Goo and Chinpokomon to name a couple) and a lot of them are cleverly placed.

South Park: The Stick of Truth is a fantastic turn-based RPG and doesn't disappoint. The game feels like a very long episode of South Park and it actually looks like one too. I can recommend this to people who have only seen the show a few times and you'll still love it to death. 10/10.

reviewText:
South Park: The Stick of Truth, to be honest is a milestone in gaming in my eyes. Not only is this licensed game functioning and playable, it's actually good. No, it's more than good. It's brilliant. The gameplay and world fits the South Park license so well and as a long time fan of the series, I've nothing but praise for this game.

When I first heard about Stick of Truth, I wasn't too excited. Licensed Games weren't exactly high art and I wasn't a fan of the Lord of the Rings setting because the only South Park episode with that setting I really liked was Return of the Fellowship of The Ring. But when more information came out about it, it slowly began to win me over. This wasn't this setting. It was a parody. It was still the characters and universe that we knew and loved, but using the LoTR settings as a tounge and cheek joke and it honestly worked in my eyes.

The gameplay really does fit the South Park setting with it being totally in 2D and it also helps brings fun to the turn based fighting in the game. In most RPGs you just hit your attack, and then wait to dodge your enemies attack. In Stick of Truth, they've added a mechanic where you need to time your attack to get maximum damage out of it as well as other variables, such as archers, multiple hit enemies, shields, and more. It really works to help keep the game out of repetive areas in my opinion.

The graphical style is of course the same that's been featured in the show. Normally, you'd be thinking lol how could a 2013 game have these graphics". But considering the art style and joke about the South Park style
date: I find the graphics very charming
recommended: and helping add to the feel of the SP universe.\n\nOn top of that the game is absolutely filled to the brim with nothing but in-jokes
hoursPlayed: references

reviewText:
This is the greatest South Park game of all time. In its own right, this is a pretty great adventure/JRPG hybrid. Although every game mechanic has been used hundreds of times in every game, they've never been combined in such a way like this before. A JRPG with a full collect-a-thon system set in South Park, CO? That's a huge undertaking, and Obsidian have stepped up to the plate.

The game is also relatively bug free, although its menus and interface look like ♥♥♥. I have to assume that they did not have an interface designer, because the interface is both ugly and hard to use. Luckily, it's not too important, and beyond that the game is quite beautiful in its own South Park way.

The biggest selling point of this game is the ability to play the game and have a hard time finding graphical inconsistencies that make it seem like you're not just watching an episode of South Park. This is a long, 15-hour episode of South Park, and it is pretty fantastic.

However, do not buy the DLC. I picked them both up, and never used the equipment and items provided by the DLC.

reviewText:
This is a shockingly fun and well made game. It harkens back to classic RPGs while still having a free-roam style feel. Also has various nerd references to Lord of the Rings, Game of Thrones, and other medieval fantasy realms. As well, of course, the many references to classic south park episodes that make you chuckle. Walk around and fart on people and see their reaction. Rummage through the town for money or items to sell and buy new gear and such.

If you love South Park, do yourself a favor and buy this game. and hour+ into it and I'm already loving every minute.

I do not have much criticism on the game yet. Sure, there are always things people want to see change. I have not spotted too many issues or anything yet. But then again, I'm no critic. I simply speak as a South Park and Stone/Parker fan when I say congratulations to them for making a fun and truely fantastic RPG. It is like playing a great episode of South Park.

NOTE: I will edit this post eventually to note any critcisms (If any). This will never change my reccomendation of this game

SOUTH PARK LOVERS MUST BUY!!!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This happens if you get the makers of South Park and the developers of Fallout create a game similar to Paper Mario gameplay in the South Park universe, with LoTR theme and references from other fantasy games.

Never laughed this much in a while. And I couldn't put the controller down. Played 13 hours within a day and completed the main story plus some exploring and a bit of side quests with 50% achievements completion. Doing all the side quests would probably take you 30+ hours.

Not much replay value but you may need to do another run (with guides/walk through) if you want to perfect the achievements.

Almost perfect game. It just feels too short for an RPG game.

Overall 9/10

reviewText: A very good 12-14 hour long South Park episode, what could be bad about that?  Combat is simple and straight forward.  Exploration is rewarded with a collectibles type system. reviewText:
An absolute must play for any fan of South Park. Completely written and voiced by Trey and Matt (along with other cast members) comes a South Park experience that fans have been waiting for after several games of less than stellar quality. It is so well done that there is a real, likely chance someone will walk in the room and ask what episode you are watching. Hats off to Obsidian and Trey/Matt for really nailing the look and the feel of the show in an interactive game.

The story, much like the show, is rather absurd, crude and all around ridiculous, chalked full of classic (and possibly forgotten about) references. You are the 'New Kid' who has just moved to South Park and you start to befriend the various characters while becomming embroiled in a dangerous, enternal struggle for The Stick of Truth. There are so many great characters that show up and some that had slipped my mind completely. There was one character I was really hoping to see and didn't, but I won't spoil it on anyone.

Combat is a pretty basic turn based combat system, much like JRPG's of old with a few more interactive elements thrown in. Admittedly it is rather basic and shallow, but I feel that it serves to keep the story moving along rather than having the player getting bogged down by combat.

In the end, I think it's best to play this game simply to enjoy the story for the laughs.

reviewText: Pretty phenomenal game. If you enjoy South Park, this game is a must have. The combat is good, but it can at times be a little drawn out, but it's still engaging. The world is phenomenally well crafted, and really makes you fell like a South Park character. This game is, at its core, a long, interactive episode of South Park, and if that sounds at all interesting, then it is definitely worth the purchase.

reviewText:
General Idea If you enjoy the show South Park, then you will enjoy this game! That being said, if you don't like the show, then you probably won't enjoy this game, as it is basically a 16 hour playable episode.

Gameplay This game is absolutely hilarious! What you see in the TV show is pretty much what you can expect to see in this game. You can go into most buildings and houses.  In some houses that you try to enter, you will find people masturbating, people screwing horses, or naked dancing ladies.  You can raid people's houses of all their personal belongings and valuables, and nobody gives a damn. The only authority to you really is your parents,  and in one mission a hall monitor, but they don't really count.  There is a point at the beginning of the game when you realize that a fart is bound to the right mouse button. It is at that moment that you will realize what kind of game this is. You probably will love it from this moment on, as most players probably did. The missions are intriguing, and humor is scattered throughout the game everywhere. The one thing people may not like is the combat style. It is a turn-based combat sort of like the game Wizard101. This game is pretty much a single player RPG. You do missions and fight to get experience and level up. As you gain Facebook friends with the people throughout South Park, you will be able to upgrade your player.

Levels I will start by saying that the max level in this game is level 15. It is like many other RPGs, in that all items have a level requirement. I must say, in my opinion, that it takes a while to level up. In just about 9 hours of gameplay, I have only gotten to level 13. Based on this, it probably takes between 10-12 hours to get to level 15 and complete one of the classes.

Campaign You start the campaign as the new kid who just moved to South Park, CO and the hope is that you will help the humans secure the Stick of Truth so that they can rule the universe. The war is between the Humans, led by Cartman, and the Elves, led by Kyle. There are 4 different classes you can choose to be, and they are:  Fighter, Mage, Thief,  and  Jew.   You are able to type a name in at the beginning of the game, but you are assigned the name ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥" by Cartman.  The campaign is very fun and immersive
date: and you could easily find yourself sitting and playing this game for hours at a time. You will find out that it can be very hard to get up and stop playing this game. After you complete the campaign
hoursPlayed: there is nearly no drive to keep playing the game.\n\nConclusion In my opinoin

reviewText:
This is the greatest South Park game of all time. In its own right, this is a pretty great adventure/JRPG hybrid. Although every game mechanic has been used hundreds of times in every game, they've never been combined in such a way like this before. A JRPG with a full collect-a-thon system set in South Park, CO? That's a huge undertaking, and Obsidian have stepped up to the plate.

The game is also relatively bug free, although its menus and interface look like ♥♥♥. I have to assume that they did not have an interface designer, because the interface is both ugly and hard to use. Luckily, it's not too important, and beyond that the game is quite beautiful in its own South Park way.

The biggest selling point of this game is the ability to play the game and have a hard time finding graphical inconsistencies that make it seem like you're not just watching an episode of South Park. This is a long, 15-hour episode of South Park, and it is pretty fantastic.

However, do not buy the DLC. I picked them both up, and never used the equipment and items provided by the DLC.

reviewText:
First off, let me start by saying this game is FANTASTIC. I'm not a huge turn based RPG player, but I picked up the game with skepticism because I'd heard good things about it and it's South Park.

The game is funny and engaging. It has a lot to do and I found myself spending entire afternoons and evenings playing this game (which I don't do very often). As I walked around South Park doing side quests I found myself laughing at the dialogue of people I passed by or my buddy when I did certain things or went certain places. There are so many Easter Eggs in this game that you can find while walking around looting (Butters' Creamy Goo and Chinpokomon to name a couple) and a lot of them are cleverly placed.

South Park: The Stick of Truth is a fantastic turn-based RPG and doesn't disappoint. The game feels like a very long episode of South Park and it actually looks like one too. I can recommend this to people who have only seen the show a few times and you'll still love it to death. 10/10.

reviewText: BR review, translate it if you want.\nPROS: Jogo sensacional, animações incríveis, vibrantes, diálogos engraçados, história que te prende (você sente que fumou uma droga braba mesmo sem ter feito isso, cenas engraçadas-porém-sem-sentido todo o tempo), oferece a possibilidade de lutar contra inimigos/bosses usando um Buddy (as principais crianças de South Park) e cada inimigo tem um ponto fraco nas lutas; seja fire damage, gross damage etc. Você pode usar um item de cada vez durante o combate: pode usar uma pequena ou grande poção de cura, pode te dar força, atacar novamente, sem contar as Habilidades de cada personagem, cada um tem 3 habilidades especiais e distintas que podem tirar mais vida que um ataque de espada ou arco e flecha se você souber usar corretamente. Pode ir ao banheiro - literalmente - e pegar uma amostra de suas fezes e jogar no inimigo, fazendo-o perder vida com gross damage. Aliás, andando pela cidade, o botão esquerdo bate em alguém e o botão direito peida. Você pode encontrar Jesus no jogo, assim como na série... Uma coisa interessante e necessária neste jogo é que você é capaz de upar, ganha experiência em cada combate que entra (se você perder, o jogo volta pro último checkpoint), sua vida aumenta automaticamente conforme seu nível e você também pode usar armaduras, luvas, capacetes com inúmeras funções (pode escolher um aprimoramento extra em cada vestimenta, junto com as armas).\nCON: Embora tenham tantos pros - citei os que consegui lembrar - não acho que este jogo valha R$80 (brazilian currency), justamente por ser um jogo relativamente curto... Acho que 15 horas jogando é o suficiente para zerar. Mesmo que a história seja tão bem preparada, pelo menos no MEU ponto de vista ainda tem aquela enrolação, o final do game não acabou alcançando minhas expectativas, mas a história em si, durante o jogo, é bem divertida. O pior contra pra mim foi o combate com os inimigos/bosses, eles vêm com quase 40000 de vida, e não se engane achando que vem só um inimigo assim: em todas as batalhas, eles chamam pelo menos 3 amiguinhos pra ajuda-los com uns 8000 de vida, curando um ao outro quando a vida de um diminui e cada um tem uma vez de atacar você e seu Buddy, só depois vocês podem ataca-los, enquanto você tem menos de 8000 de vida (quase chegando no nível máximo, que é lvl 15). Sem contar quase no fim da quest principal que começa a vir personagens zumbis, ou seja, mais fortes, resistentes e o pior de tudo: eles revivem. Um exemplo: você está lá na batalha e mata um ou dois soldados" do boss
date: ele simplesmente se cura e revive os dois zumbis com a vida máxima. Acaba sendo decepcionante

reviewText:
SOUTH PARK: THE STICK OF TRUTH REVIEW
South Park: The Stick of Truth  is easily one of the funniest games I have ever played. The game visually is exactly the same as the show and on-point at that. The story is completely ridiculous, over the top, and extremely good. You are basically playing a long episode of South Park which is sick af. There seems to be a lack of soundtrack variety, but the soundtracks that are in the game are simply brilliant and are amazing which makes up for the minimal amount found in the game in my opinion. The game is a role-playing game and the RPG elements are surprisingly well thoughtout and very diverse for a game like this. The game is my Game of the Year of 2014".

THE FUNNIEST ROLE-PLAYING GAME TO EVER TOUCH THIS EARTH. 10/10"

reviewText:
There aren't too many 'funny' games that have come out in the past ten years. You have Portal along with a few other gems here and there that have had competent comedic writers, but for the most part every other game is 10-15 years old borrowed internet humor (see: star wars kid, all your base belongs to us, Leroy Jenkins) or cringeworthy regurgitated memes from the depths of 9gag/Reddit (Borderlands 2).

South Park: The Stick of Truth on the other hand has made me laugh quite a bit. If you're a fan of the earlier seasons of the show (season 1-5) like me, then you'll love this game since it includes a lot of the highlighted references throughout the entire game along with other later episodes from the mid 2000's such as Al Gore and Christmas Critters. Best part is, it does not contain any celebrities or product placement that has plagued the show for the past ten years...outside of Taco Bell.

The game is pretty damn short and linear but everything feels like South Park and it genuinely feels like you're in an episode of the show. Each battle is hilarious, especially the boss battles like with Al Gore and the Underpants Gnomes and the special attacks are icing on the cake, especially Kenny's chance of dying. I wish they did something more like make jabs at other games, the game industry, or game journalist like they do with celebrities or well known people on the show. The game is also pretty easy, but you have an option to make it harder.

Good game and I would recommend it...only when it's on sale though just because of the length of the game. Somewhere between $5-$15. $30 is just not worth it, unless you're a hardcore South Park fan.

Also, the sequel I'm not too sure about. I think The Coon and the superhero thing that's been going on for almost 8 years was a lowlight of the show. That's my personal opinion, so let's hope the sequel is more in depth and as funny as the original.

reviewText:
Don't bother with the DLC, the way it was worded I thought it was additional classes or perks but it's level 1 armor that gets out classed after a few minutes into the game. My fault for not reading it clearly.

Amazing game with 15-20 hours worth of content. Plays like Mario RPG or Costume Quest, a turn based RPG with timed attack and defense indicators that require button presses to execute.

Picked it up and didn't play anything else until I was finished. It was that good.

The voice acting is as good as an episode of the show. The plot and dialog was excellent with call backs to various episodes so an avid South Park watcher would definitely enjoy the familiarity of the setting and characters.

reviewText:
It does feel like you are in a South Park episode, being able to roam the town, apart from the unlockables and the sidequests make the exploration enjoyable. The writing and the pacing of the story are great and most of the jokes deliver. The plot does have a lot of twists and turns so you never feel like it gets stale. There are a ton of references to the show too.

On the badside, the game is rather short and the combat is somewhat inconsistent, also if you have played rpg's before the game becomes too easy. Also the classes dont affect the gameplay that much apart from the name.

reviewText: South Park: The Stick of Truth is everything that fans of both South Park and classic turn-based RPGs are looking for. It plays just like an episode of South Park, and it's snarky humor and references to the show are great. I find myself unable to put it away sometimes, simply because it's a blast to play through, and it's hilarious. The replayability has a pretty steep dropoff, since after just a couple of playthroughs you've pretty much seen all the game has to offer, but I still find myself going back just for the pure entertainment. Definite 9/10.

reviewText:
South Park: The Stick of Truth is a faithful to the show rpg-lite adventure into the life of the new kid. You can expect all the vulgarity and over the top situations that are in the show along with various nods to the show itself like songs such as love gravy" and "i've got something in my front pocket for you".

Many a number of the main characters make appearences in the game with the most recognizable being available as buddies that fight alongside you. Butters is the first of such allies and features a special attack where he transforms into Professor Chaos.

The game also features four classes. Mage
recommended: thief and Jew. All with their unique abilities such as the Jew classes "sling of david"\n\nThe game is a short outing with available sidequests
hoursPlayed: you can expect a playtime without dong any side quests to be around\n12-14 hours. Definately quite short for the genre
voteText:
though I wouldn't consider it a full fledged rpg.

The game provides excellent fan service and a true to the show animation and visual presentation.

Highly recommended for die-hard fans of the show."

reviewText:
This game is very fun. First off, you have a looting mechanic which is something I love in games. You also have interesting and hilarious dialogue, quests, and even interfaces. Everything in this game is well crafted and those familiar to the universe of South Park should be easily amused by this game.

My only issue is the pushy fart jokes, but thats just me.

At some moments I feel this game matches Fallout in terms of enjoyment. I highly recommend it.

reviewText: South Park The Stick Of Truth is exactly what you'd thought it would be. It's hilarious, over the top and fun. The writing is top notch, it's like you're in the show when you play. The combat is fun, fast and easy to pick up. Nothing too hard there. There are tons of collectables and people to talk to that will keep you busy for hours and hours. You're constantly unlocking new abilities that grant you access to more and more areas as well. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the show. The sheer amount of crossover from the show to the game is amazing. You'll love it.

reviewText:
This is probably the best South Park game one could hope for, and it's one of the best and most fulfilling games I've played in recent years.

For one, the sidequests don't feel tacked-on.
They're an integral part of the whole, and they're actually worth doing in order to receive some more hilarious rewards.

The combat is simple, but it does feel as rewarding as in any other turn-based RPG to see the high numbers fly.

The length of the game is perfect.
It took me about 16 hours of gameplay in order to wrap up all of the collectables, sidequests, and main story missions.

On top of all of this, it looks and sounds amazing as well.

Definite must-own for the South Park fan, and potential gateway drug for the fan-recruit.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
♥♥♥♥ jokes - check.
Shameless and merciless satire - check.
Kenny dies - check.
Exploration - check.
QTE that doesn't annoy the ♥♥♥♥ out of me - check.

Seriously, get this game right now if you had ever watched at least one episode of South Park and laughed. It's everything you could expect from a bunch of episodes of the show bundled with gameplay that does not suck.

It's also worth mentioning that I'm not a fan of the show. I've only seen a couple of episodes and actually quite liked them. So it's not like you have to watch every episode of South Park to enjoy this game.

Also, Obsidian Entertainment did quite an awesome job this time, I've expected the game to have much more bugs.

PS. The game is pretty easy. I've played it on hard difficulty, and even that felt like a walk in the park. Still, I wouldn't say that challenge is the most important thing in this game, but it's definitely lacking most of the time.

voteText: all sorts of crazy adventures and humorous catastrophes happen. The story is very good and the progression in this

votesTotal: insanity and sexuality mixed in with a nice amount of violence left me laughing out loud more times I can remember. If you like South Park humour the game is certainly required in your game collection.\nThe gameplay is nothing elaborate or even diffecult. You wander around on maps

column20: which you can defend yourself from.\nThe graphics and sound are the same as in the series
column21: though there was a part in the game that changed considerably. I wont spoil anything in this review
column22: but I can tell that I liked the retro-feel of it
column23: and in combination with the story it was a little detail that left me smiling and laughing.\nThe game in itself would be 5 out of 5 stars from me. This however leaving out the price of the game and also the replay value. There are some small elements of choice in the game

date: I have never touched a cigarette. I must say
recommended: I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it

reviewText: Good game.\nYou can create your character at the start and then choose a class and unlock powers. The combat is turn-based and is quite challenging at times. You have your main quest, as well as side quests which you can do whenever you want. The world is interact-able and has things to use which you unlock later to collect more Chimpokemon, which are the collectables in this game. The game takes about 8 to 12 hours to complete the game with just the mian quest but will take an extra hour or two to do all the side quests as well.

reviewText:
The Stick of Truth is an excellent... South Park episode. And there's really nothing more to add. If not the license and your typical SP writing composed of every single possible reference to every episode ever, nobody would even notice this game exists. That's due to stale as ♥♥♥♥ gameplay that is mediocre even if compared to early 2000's Newground's browser games.
Holy ♥♥♥♥ the combat with mashing your buttons when the game tells you. If not Cartman's fiery ♥♥♥ or the Lady from the Stonebury Hollow song I would drop this crap after the tutorial.
Other than that, it's a looting nightmare with some blocked out locations until you get a story-related skill (the alien probe, the gnome's coke or another fart spell).

It's worth buying for few €, who wouldn't watch a super-long SP episode?

reviewText: I don't generally like South Park's sense of humor as a television show.  Shock humor doesn't tend to offend me, I just usually don't find it that funny.  Moreover, Trey and Matt's middle finger to the world, everything is equally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t social and political commentary can be grating; it is both intellectually shallow and safe.  Having said that
date: South Park: The Stick of Truth is a fantastic game.  It's like a raunchy Earthbound with Super Mario RPG style timed battle mechanics.  The world of modern day kids playing make believe fantasy is fantastic setting for an RPG and feels really fresh. You really never really know where the game will take you next. And the game mines alot of RPG and videogame tropes for some pretty funny humor.  It doesn't waste your time will filler content; it's a tightly edited
recommended: sleek 12-14 hour package.  Some of the attempts at humor may make you roll your eyes a bit
hoursPlayed: but Stick of Truth is a game regardless.  But perhaps most surprising
voteText: despite the abuse and ridicule it sometimes dishes out to it's characters
helpfulPercent: it is clearly game that has a lot of heart and views its characters endearingly.  It's Charlie Brown for a more cynical era combined with a well crafted RPG. Recommended."

reviewText:
Having seen all episodes of the show, the movies, and any tv specials that have to do with Matt Stone and Trey Parker, I can say this has everything for the most hardcore fan. Tons of references from the show and movie. The combat is highly simplified and gets extremely tedious and repetitive, but you can't expect much from combat from a South Park rpg. No matter which class you pick it always makes sense to still equip the weapon that does the most dmg and the gear that gives the most armor, so most gear in the game is worthless. It has a really fun story and a lot of great humor, although personally I did not care much for the ending. I thought it was kinda stupid and kind of a cop out and it could have been much more epic. As it was, the ending was pretty non-epic. Overall it is a mediocre rpg, but a fantastic South Park themed game that has more than enough characters and references for any SP fan. Non fans should pass this up because it really was made for SP fans directly. In any other game this would be a terribly simplistic rpg. But considering all past South Park games have all been horrible garbage, this is pretty good for a South Park game. Still not worth more than one playthrough. Very faithfully represents the show in all aspects but is dragged down somewhat by highly repetitive and extremely tedious combat.

6/10 combat.
6/10 gameplay.
5/10 rpg elements.
10/10 faithfully represents South Park in great detail.
7/10 overall. Buy on sale for a once through.

reviewText:
Apparently this game has strong ties with its TV show counterpart, but I am being ignorant for it as I've never even heard it, so this review is based on purely the gameplay/technical aspect of the game alone.

South Park is a light RPG with cartoonish graphic which is full of (apparently) comedy from start to finish. I am not a type that can stomach this kind of disgusting jokes in-game, though.

From a quick glance, you might think it's suitable for children, but no it's not. Even the rating says it's not, so don't ever let your children/kids play this game.

The gameplay is fairly simple, you control one character on 2D map, can move right left to explore the areas, unlock new rooms and do some quests to progress. The map is fairly large, but there's a quick travel (think about Waypoints in Diablo 3) so you can deliver quest items around faster.

Being an RPG, there's bound to be battle screen. The battle screen is loaded when your character comes in contact with enemy - more or less Mapped Enemies - so there's no annoying random battles, because you can avoid battles if you want (except boss battles or forced fights). When in battle your 2 characters take turns like traditional RPGs, can use items, skills or magic. The standard aspect of RPG battles still applies here, as enemies often have strong resistance against certain elements, so you need to research the enemies first before attacking.

The sound/OSTs are so so for my taste, nothing really caught my attention. But the good side is that the game is fully voiced, meaning you will hear characters speaking whether in battle or in map/normal exploration.

From technical side, I've heard about a bug where you will get skipped cutscene during certain event, see this link: South Park Wiki, but I didn't encounter it. Still, I did as what advised and saved my game before it's too late. As a whole, the game is very smooth on maxed settings on my laptop, and I can play with my xinput Logitech F310 controller without issue as well.

Once you beat the game, it won't end like Final Fantasy 7 for example, where you can only replay the game from your last savepoint. You'll be allowed to return to the map to continue your sidequests, along with your latest equipments, that you haven't finished. But there are missables so if you fail to get them in the first place, you need to restart your playthrough from the beginning / new save.

DLCs are garbage, don't buy them - what an awful quick cash grab from Ubisoft, but it's to be expected. However, for some unknown reason, this version does NOT contain uPlay. Hooraaaaayyyyy! One of redeeming point of this game for me.

So am I going to recommend the game? Absolutely, despite its flaws for me, but only when it's discounted. I personally paid this game for like 2 USD on legitimate/endorsed Steam key distributor for 12-15 hours of entertainment - well worth it. So if you haven't bought it, chances are you will be able to get the same price like me in the future.

6/10 - barely-made-it score.

reviewText:
Some of the best 11 hours of my life. I'm not even done with the game yet (I plan to do all the sidequests. I completed the main story, and I thought it was hilarious all the way through.)

I can't think of anything bad about this game. I've been a longtime fan of South Park. I love the show, and playing this was my first experience with their games (I hear the others are really bad but, I don't know first hand). I laughed all the way through, I thought the gameplay was amazing, and it was great. Normally I hate turn-based games, with few exceptions like Pokemon or old Final Fantasy or Paper Mario. This game actually brought me a feeling of nostalgia, not just because I watched South Park throughout my life, but the nostalgia of using the turn-based system that's comparable to Paper Mario. Take the combat of Paper Mario, and the ridiculousness and humor of South Park, and you've got an amazing game.

10/10 would go to Ottawa again.

reviewText:
I'm a fan of Obsidian, and a slightly-above-casual fan of South Park, and this is essentially an episode -- actually multiple episodes -- that you control. For some people, that would be enough. For me, I felt this was Obsidian's weakest game and filled with more bugs than expected in one of their non-open-world efforts.

The game is a linear adventure -- definitely not an RPG -- and the fights are a weird mix of QTEs and turn-based battles. The game outside of combat is fetch quests and collect-them-all activities.

On the other hand, the narrative itself is very entertaining, the voice acting is superb (although there is a problem with the audio sync), and... well, it's South Park, so hilariously offensive. Tremendous amount of fan service here.

So is it a great game? No, not quite. Is it worth playing? If you're a South Park fan, absolutely. Just don't be mislead by the developer's pedigree and the description into thinking this is anything but a 20-hour linear adventure.

reviewText: If you're a fan of South Park the show, then chances are you'll be a fan of the game.  I was wary at first because I loathe turn-based RPG games, but in true South Park fashion the game parodies the mechanics to make it fun to play and challenging (at least to non-TBRPG players).    You play the new kid in town who finds himself caught in a power struggle over The Stick of Truth between the Cartman-led humans and the Kyle-led Elves.  Naturally, there's more to the Stick of Truth than either of these two sides realize, and soon you find yourself the only one who can save the town of South Park from an unforseen darkness!  The whole town is there for the player to explore and fart on when not doing the story missions.  The developers took the time to include as many main and side characters in the show's lore as the game could hold I think, and really helps with the feeling that you are IN South Park.  The only drawbacks are the story campaign is almost too short, sometimes the keyboard controls are not instantly intuitive, and mission objectives can be VERY vague leaving one to wonder, what the hell am I suppossed to do??"\n\nPros:  Excellent production design: Visuals
date: sound effects all straight fromt he show itself.  Voice acting is top-notch to go along with the great writing.  Main and side quests vary and are fun to play through.  Lots of options for different types of play: Warrior
hoursPlayed: Jew
voteText: etc.\n\nCons: A bit on the short side
helpfulPercent: limited replayability unless you want to explore all the different character classes
votesHelpful: keyboard controls for certain powers can be confusing
votesTotal: vague mission objectives at times.\n\nAgain
votesFunny: fans of the show should enjoy it since it's about as close to playing an episode of South Park as one can get."

reviewText:
YES - This is THE game for South Park fans! And I would go so far as to call this one of the best licensed games ever created. It really does capture the full feel of the South Park world, with the legitimate crude humor thanks to the involvement of the creators.

There are tons of references to many events throughout the South Park episodes and movies, and discovering them will feel rewarding, though most of these references do not play much role in the story.

Who do I recommend it to?

South Park fans; For certain! The more you have watched of the show, the better, to get more of the references. However, it isn't essential to have watched all of the show to still enjoy the scenarios, story, and humor.

Non-South park fans; I would generally not recommend it simply because it is that faithful to south park, so if you do not like south park you likely won't like this. However, there is always a chance that this could serve like a different way to gain a taste for the show.

The downside; I do wish it could have been much longer. Ironically, because the game put the universe together so beautifully I was left wanting even more, despite it having an already great playability time.

As one whom is a strong South Park fan (having watched every single episode of the show, and the movies as well), I give it a strong 8.5/10.

Here's hoping for a sequel or expansion!

reviewText:
This is a surprisingly delightful, long, and non-linear RPG that rewards exploration and experimentation, has lots of worthwhile and fun side-quests and achievements, all wrapped around an excellent story that is full of unexpected twists.

It is also a ridiculously funny South Park episode, which is centered around a parody of the fantasy RPG genre. Note, though, that you won't find any new components: all the characters, gags, songs, and themes have already been used and abused to death on the TV show. I guess it's inevitable that a TV show that has been running for so long has to get so self-referential. But, well, some things are always funny. Like farts.

To fully enjoy this game, you MUST play it with a gamepad/controller, as it makes ingenious use of its physicality and vibrations. I played with an Xbox-compatible one, which was recognized without any configuration.

I say surprising" because I was expecting a casual gaming experience with the South Park story at its center. But it's actually a very sophisticated game

reviewText: I'm happy to say I can jump on the bandwagon with this one; the game is phenominal! It plays like an interactive episode of the show, with Trey and Matt keeping exactly the same quality as you would find simply watching. Gameplay is very good and definitely fun, the biggest issues being a lack of balance between weapons and armor, and certain armor patches not working (X% weapon damage, thorns damage apparently being applied to your weapon) but they're easily ignored as you have fun exploring the town and hearing Butters or Cartman spout their usual banter.\n\nThe only people I might not recommend this to are people not familiar with the show, but even then, credit should be given to Oblivion for helping flesh out what was essentially a 2-parter parody episode, and giving it a life of its own. My biggest regret is not picking up the game sooner. If you're somehow still on the fence about this, don't be. Worth every (Canadian) dollar.

Who played it? What did everyone think. I just beat it and I know it is not even out everywhere in the world yet. I give it an 8.7 out of 10. I do this because I both love South Park, and turn based RPG's. It was really up my alley. This is the first time in a long time that I have enjoyed playing every minute of a game up until the very end.... Which brings me to the only downside... I have 12 hours played and I beat it. Now I know there is likely another 3 or 4 hours of side content in there... But I am max level... I have the best equipment... I can run around looking behind buildings and getting lost in the sewers trying to collect every last friend and chimpokemon (Spelling pending) but I just do not find joy in that. The other issue being it is a 60$ game... It is very hard to justify that price tag when Skyrim is sitting at the same for literally unlimited content... Not saying they are comparable genre wise really. I am just noting total play hours.( Do not get too hung up on why Skyrim is completely unlike SP, I know; thanks.) Do not focus on that negative part of the review though. The whole thing was hilarious as one would expect. I was worried it would be funny in the beginning and then trail off and I must say I think it was a snowball getting funnier and funnier until the very last moment.

BUY IT!

-Russell Lowman

reviewText:
A solid game that seems to hit that sweet spot between too much simplicity and being overly complex, particularly with the combat system. The combat is one of the highlights, with the kids using common household items for weapons and armor, and the system is deeper than you might imagine, but still simple enough to remain immersed within the story.

And what a story it is. Many have said it already, but this is just like playing through several episodes of South Park. There will be all the jokes you might expect from the show, so those who are easily offended (or have no idea what South Park is – where have you been living the past 15 years or so?) might want to give the game a pass. In fact, it's more like South Park the Movie, as it can get away with a lot more than the show itself can.

With tons of characters to befriend and items to find, as well as four classes to play through as, there is plenty of reason to replay the game at least one more time to see it all, for roughly 30 hours total.

reviewText: This feels like a long, interactive episode of South Park, complete with satirical jabs at gaming conventions (Audio logs and Nazi zombies, anyone?). The combat is also a very solid, familiar turn-based structure, but with the added flair of timed blocks and attacks, so it's not quite as set-and-forget as Final Fantasy and the like. Customization is quite varied, both cosmetic and strategic. You'll often find yourself poring over weapon and gear attachments, debating the merit of stacking certain debuffs or rigging up an anti-armor set instead. The main questline itself, yes, is about four hours long. However, this ignores the gigantic array of worthwhile side quests, which are absolutely worth noting. Replay value is also high, with four classes to choose from, each with a unique array of powers for different playstyles. Long-time fans of South Park will recognize a lot of recurring jokes both new and old, and newcomers will get a pretty strong feel for the show, in a good way. While it is absolutely worth your time, I do strongly suggest waiting for a sale. While it may be Trey and Matt's first real game, in a lot of ways it feels better planned out and executed than a lot of games released by veteran studios today. Absolutely recommended. 10/10
